Ryanair pulls 12 routes in leasing dispute with regulator
Ryanair pulls 12 routes in leasing dispute with regulator
Financial Times (London, England)
December 23, 2020 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS; Pg. 9
Length: 376 words
Byline: PHILIP GEORGIADIS
Body
Ryanair has cancelled 12 of its UK domestic and international routes after a disagreement with the UK's regulator 
that the carrier said left operation "impossible" ahead of Brexit.
The low-cost Irish carrier secured an operating licence for its UK subsidiary nearly two years ago to allow it to keep 
UK traffic rights and protect its operations from January 1 when the Brexit transition period ends.
The aim was to ensure it could continue to fly inside the UK, and to countries outside the EU such as Morocco. But 
Ryanair said the Civil Aviation Authority introduced regulatory barriers on Sunday evening, just 10 days before the 
transition ends. The airline did not elaborate, but the CAA said Ryanair was planning to use leased, foreignowned 
aircraft on its UK operations. "It has been our longstanding position that a UK airline with a significant presence in 
the UK, such as Ryanair UK does, should not rely heavily on using wet-leased, foreign-registered aircraft to 
undertake their operations. Doing so undermines the competitiveness of the UK aviation industry," said the CAA.
Wet leases involve aircraft being leased along with crew, maintenance and insurance.
Ryanair has only one aircraft listed on the UK's register, out of the more than 450 in its fleet. It said the changes 
affect routes from London, Manchester, Liverpool, Edinburgh, Belfast and Derry. "Ryanair UK had agreed Brexit 
contingency arrangements with the CAA two years ago and cannot comply with its new and impractical 
requirements at 10 days' notice," the airline said.
Ryanair pulls 12 routes in leasing dispute with regulator
The regulator said: "It is incorrect for the airline to state that the UK Civil Aviation Authority has changed its 
wetleasing policy at short notice."
An industry executive said Ryanair had been trying to use foreign-owned aircraft in its UK unit because of the 
disruption caused by Covid-19, leading it to fall foul of the rules.
Ryanair has long been confident it could operate uninterrupted regardless of the outcome of the Brexit talks so long 
as a basic contingency arrangement to keep planes in the air was agreed.
But the issue highlights the potential for pitfalls the UK's separation from the EU throws up for airlines that have 
long prospered from near total freedom of the skies in the EU's single market.
Load-Date: December 22, 2020
End of Document
Ryanair pulls routes over leasing dispute with regulator
Ryanair pulls routes over leasing dispute with regulator
Financial Times (London, England)
December 23, 2020 Wednesday
Edition 1, USA Edition

Ryanair Holdings plc (RYA.L) (LON:RYA) Stock Passes Below 50 Day Moving Average of $15.30
Ryanair Holdings plc (RYA.L) (LON:RYA) Stock Passes Below 50 Day 
Moving Average of $15.30
American Banking and Market News
December 22, 2020 Tuesday
Copyright 2020 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 227 words
Body
Ryanair Holdings plc (RYA.L) logo Ryanair Holdings plc (RYA.L) (LON:RYA) shares crossed below its fifty day 
moving average during trading on Monday . The stock has a fifty day moving average of $15.30 and traded as low 
as $15.04. Ryanair Holdings plc (RYA.L) shares last traded at $15.40, with a volume of 1,580,403 shares changing 
hands.  
Separately, UBS Group  reiterated a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (RYA.L) in a research report on 
Monday, August 24th. 
The business's 50 day moving average is GBX 15.30 and its two-hundred day moving average is GBX 12.54. The 
firm has a market capitalization of £174.91 million and a PE ratio of -18.49. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio 
of 112.18, a current ratio of 0.87 and a quick ratio of 0.80.  
Ryanair Holdings plc (RYA.L) Company Profile (LON:RYA ) 
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Germany, and Other European countries. It is also involved in the provision of various 
ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, 
food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation and hotel services, car hire, and travel insurance through its 
Website and mobile app. 
Recommended Story: Why do companies issue stock splits? 
Load-Date: December 22, 2020
End of Document
Alaska Airlines Orders More Boeing 737 MAXs
Alaska Airlines Orders More Boeing 737 MAXs
RTT News (United States)
December 22, 2020 Tuesday
Copyright 2020 Content Engine, LLC.
All Rights Reserved
Copyright 2020 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 335 words
Byline: editorial@rttnews.com,  (RTT Staff Writer)
Body
       Alaska Airlines has ordered another 23 Boeing 737 MAXs, bringing its total order to 68 MAXs. The 737 MAXs 
will replace most of the Airbus aircraft in Alaska's fleet, the companies said in a statement.
 Alaska will have 52 options which, if fully exercised, would take the carrier to as many as 120 737 MAX aircraft.
 Boeing's best-selling aircraft 737 MAX was grounded worldwide in March 2019 after two crashes killed all 346 
people aboard Lion Air Flight 610 and Ethiopian Airlines Flight 302.
 Earlier this month, Boeing reportedly conducted its first post-grounding flight with media onboard.
 The Federal Aviation Administration in mid November lifted its 20-month safety ban on the 737 Max aircraft, and on 
November 30, it issued first airworthiness certificate for one of the new Boeing 737 Max jets.
 The new agreement between Boeing and Alaska includes mechanisms to adjust the timing of deliveries to meet 
economic conditions, giving the airline substantial flexibility to manage its fleet in step with network demand, Alaska 
said Tuesday.
 Alaska said it is scheduled to receive 13 planes in 2021; 30 in 2022; 13 in 2023; and 12 in 2024.
 Alaska's 52 aircraft options are for deliveries between 2023 to 2026.
 Last month, Alaska Airlines announced it would expand its commitment to the 737 MAX program by leasing 13 
new 737-9s while selling some A320 jets it had taken on through its acquisition of Virgin America.
 Alaska Airlines said Tuesday that the 737-9 will replace all A319 and A320 aircraft in the airline's fleet to improve 
the airline's overall operational, financial and environmental performance.
Alaska Airlines Orders More Boeing 737 MAXs
 Alaska noted that it will reduce its Airbus fleet to 10 A321neos by the summer of 2023. 
 Alaska plans to begin revenue service with its first 737-9 in March 2021, with five additional aircraft expected to 
begin flying by summer 2021.
 Earlier this month, Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY, RYA.L) placed a firm order for 75 additional 737 MAX aircraft, 
increasing its order book to 210 jets.        
Load-Date: December 23, 2020
End of Document
Tuesday Papers: UK offers cash-for-quotas fishing deal to tempt Europe
Tuesday Papers: UK offers cash-for-quotas fishing deal to tempt Europe
Citywire
December 22, 2020 Tuesday 3:23 AM GMT
Copyright 2020 Citywire Financial Publishers All Rights Reserved
Length: 771 words
Byline: Himanshu Singh
Highlight: And Boris Johnson plans mass Covid testing of lorry drivers to reopen ports.
Body
Top stories
•
The Times: Britain has tabled a compromise on fishing that could break a deadlock over compensation if 
quotas for Europe’s fleet are severely cut in future.
•
The Daily Telegraph: Boris Johnson is drawing up contingency plans to test all lorry drivers taking goods 
across the Channel in order to bring an end to the disruption at Britain’s ports.
•
Financial Times: The Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine has become the first Covid-19 shot to win approval from the 
EU medicines regulator, clearing the way for vaccinations.
•
Financial Times: Non-essential British retailers have been plunged deeper into crisis, as concern grows 
over a more infectious strain of coronavirus.
•
Financial Times: Royal Dutch Shell will slash billions of dollars from the value of its assets, signalling 
producers are adjusting to the impact of pandemic and the shift towards renewable energy.
Business and economics
•
Daily Mail: Nearly £40bn was wiped off the value of British companies yesterday as a ‘sorry cocktail’ of 
coronavirus and Brexit worries spooked the financial markets.
•
The Guardian: House prices in the UK are expected to fall by up to 5% next year, fuelled by rising 
unemployment and the end of the government’s stamp duty holiday.
•
Daily Mail: Mike Ashley’s Frasers retail empire has issued a profit warning as retailers face a much leaner 
Christmas and longer spells of restrictions than earlier hoped.
•
The Daily Telegraph: Deliveroo’s losses ballooned to almost £320m last year before its fortunes improved 
as the Covid-19 pandemic boosted demand for takeaways.
•
Daily Mail: Tesla shares fell 6.5% yesterday as it made its debut on Wall Street’s S&P 500.
•
The Guardian: Boohoo has hired a new auditor after the resignation of the ‘big four’ accountancy firm PwC 
amid accusations that workers’ health and rights had been put at risk and some were underpaid.
Tuesday Papers: UK offers cash-for-quotas fishing deal to tempt Europe

from the UK, compounding the crisis facing the aviation industry.

Financial Times: Ryanair has cancelled 12 of its UK domestic and international routes, following a 
disagreement with the UK’s regulator that left operation of the flights ‘impossible’ ahead of Brexit.
•

an influential shareholder adviser urged investors to oppose her re-election to the board over her role at 
Wirecard, the collapsed German payments company.
•
The Daily Telegraph: Apple will reportedly manufacture and sell its own electric car within four years.
•
The Daily Telegraph: Toyota plans to shut down production at its three plants in Britain and France up to 
two days early for Christmas, ‘as a result of expected parts shortages from transport delays’.
•
The Times: Informa is set to clash with shareholders over a plan to rewrite the exhibition company’s 
executive pay scheme.
•
The Times: The Financial Times is planning to cut up to 64 staff amid a backlash over a £1.9bn pay 
package for the title’s former editor.
•
The Times: The British division of the American investment platform Charles Schwab has been fined 
£8.96m by the City regulator for failing to safeguard clients’ money.
Share tips, comment and bids
•
Financial Times: Danish clean energy company Vestas is investing €500m in a tie-up with fund manager 
Copenhagen Infrastructure Partners, expanding a push into project development from the world’s largest 
wind turbine maker.
•
Daily Mail: The break-up of Philip Green’s Arcadia empire has begun with the sale of 90-year-old fashion 
brand Evans for £23m.
•
Daily Mail: Metro Bank has sold some of its mortgages to NatWest, in a move that will affect 13,000 
customers.
•
The Times: Signature Aviation, which until recently was known as BBA, said its board is minded to accept 
a £3.2bn, 386p-a-share cash offer from funds controlled by Blackstone.
•
The Times: The Co-operative Bank has ended takeover talks with the American private equity group 
Cerberus.
•
Financial Times: Private equity firm Thoma Bravo has agreed to buy the real estate software company 
RealPage in a deal that values it at $10.2bn.
•
Financial Times: SoftBank has filed to raise up to $604m for a special purpose acquisition company, saying 
the vehicle could acquire a business the Japanese conglomerate has previously invested in.
•
The Guardian (Comment): UK video game industry thrives amid lockdowns and US bidding wars.
•
The Daily Telegraph (Comment): SolarWinds: How Russian hackers dealt the US its worst cyberspace 
defeat in a decade.
•
The Times (Comment): Stock markets take turn for the worse as mutant virus runs rife.

Carriers take fresh hit as travel bans spread Airlines
Carriers take fresh hit as travel bans spread; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
December 22, 2020 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: FEATURES; Pg. 10
Length: 370 words
Byline: PHILIP GEORGIADIS
Body
Airlines cancelled scores of flights yesterday as a growing list of countries banned travel from the UK, compounding 
the crisis facing the aviation industry after a year of disruption.
Germany, France, Spain, Italy, Hong Kong and India were among those blocking people arriving from the UK in an 
effort to control the spread of a new variant of coronavirus.
Shares in big airlines were among the worst hit during a stocks sell-off across Europe as easyJet and IAG, owner of 
British Airways, led the falls, with losses of nearly 10 per cent each. Lower-cost carriers less exposed to the UK 
market and continental carriers suffered less steep falls, with Ryanair and Air France-KLM each down about 5 per 
cent.
The UK on Saturday placed London and south-east England under strict lockdown, banning all non-essential travel, 
and warned that a new mutation of Covid-19 was up to 70 per cent more transmissible, prompting countries to 
respond with travel bans. Flights were cancelled at airports across the UK, from Edinburgh to Birmingham, as the 
travel restrictions took hold.
There were more than 900 daily flights between the UK and EU countries last week, and data from Eurocontrol 
showed that air traffic was nudging higher prior to the travel bans which began to take hold yesterday. "We'll see a 
significant impact on the network as a result of the new variant in the UK," Eurocontrol head Eamon Brennan said.
Aviation analysts said the rise in festive bookings would have offered a cash lifeline after the collapse in revenues.
Carriers take fresh hit as travel bans spread Airlines
Daniel Roeska, an analyst at Bernstein, said IAG and easyJet were facing questions over whether they would need 
more resources to see them through until traffic returns to normal levels.
"Any worsening cash flow trends ... increase pressure on companies to find more liquidity, and if debt capital 
markets remain sluggish, a renewed equity raise may be the only way out," he said.
Paul Charles, whose PC Agency advises more than 30 companies, said about 250,000 travellers would be affected 
if disruption lasted until January 1. Gatwick said 46 flights in and out of the airport were cancelled as of late Monday 
morning. Heathrow was unable to give an update on how many flights had been cancelled.
Graphic
 
Many countries banned travel from the UK after coronavirus mutated
Load-Date: December 21, 2020
End of Document

if disruption lasted until January 1. Gatwick said 46 flights in and out of the airport were cancelled as of late Monday 
morning. Heathrow was unable to give an update on how many flights had been cancelled.

Many countries banned travel from the UK after coronavirus mutated

Carriers take fresh hit as travel bans spread; Airlines
Carriers take fresh hit as travel bans spread; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
December 22, 2020 Tuesday
Edition 1, Asian Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: FEATURES; Pg. 8
Length: 370 words
Byline: PHILIP GEORGIADIS
Body
Airlines cancelled scores of flights yesterday as a growing list of countries banned travel from the UK, compounding 
the crisis facing the aviation industry after a year of disruption.
Germany, France, Spain, Italy, Hong Kong and India were among those blocking people arriving from the UK in an 
effort to control the spread of a new variant of coronavirus.
Shares in big airlines were among the worst hit during a stocks sell-off across Europe as easyJet and IAG, owner of 
British Airways, led the falls, with losses of nearly 10 per cent each. Lower-cost carriers less exposed to the UK 
market and continental carriers suffered less steep falls, with Ryanair and Air France-KLM each down about 5 per 
cent.
The UK on Saturday placed London and south-east England under strict lockdown, banning all non-essential travel, 
and warned that a new mutation of Covid-19 was up to 70 per cent more transmissible, prompting countries to 
respond with travel bans. Flights were cancelled at airports across the UK, from Edinburgh to Birmingham, as the 
travel restrictions took hold.
There were more than 900 daily flights between the UK and EU countries last week, and data from Eurocontrol 
showed that air traffic was nudging higher prior to the travel bans which began to take hold yesterday. "We'll see a 
significant impact on the network as a result of the new variant in the UK," Eurocontrol head Eamon Brennan said.
Aviation analysts said the rise in festive bookings would have offered a cash lifeline after the collapse in revenues.
Carriers take fresh hit as travel bans spread; Airlines
Daniel Roeska, an analyst at Bernstein, said IAG and easyJet were facing questions over whether they would need 
more resources to see them through until traffic returns to normal levels.
"Any worsening cash flow trends ... increase pressure on companies to find more liquidity, and if debt capital 
markets remain sluggish, a renewed equity raise may be the only way out," he said.
Paul Charles, whose PC Agency advises more than 30 companies, said about 250,000 travellers would be affected 
if disruption lasted until January 1. Gatwick said 46 flights in and out of the airport were cancelled as of late Monday 
morning. Heathrow was unable to give an update on how many flights had been cancelled.
Graphic
 
Many countries banned travel from the UK after coronavirus mutated
Load-Date: December 21, 2020
End of Document
Ryanair Cancels 12 British Routes Citing Change in Brexit Policy by the CAA
Ryanair Cancels 12 British Routes Citing Change in Brexit Policy by the CAA
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
December 22, 2020 Tuesday 00:27
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 173 words
Body
 Ryanair Holdings (RYA.L, RY4C.IR) canceled 12 international and domestic routes in the UK due to a change in 
Brexit-related policy by the British Civil Aviation Authority, Reuters reported Monday, sending shares over 5% down 
on Monday's close.
The budget airline said its British unit had finalized contingency arrangements two years back with the regulator, but 
the rules were changed on Sunday.
However, the regulator said that it was "incorrect for the airline to state that the UK Civil Aviation Authority has 
changed its wet-leasing policy at short notice."
"It has been our long-standing position that a UK airline with a significant presence in the UK, such as Ryanair UK 
does, should not rely heavily on using wet-leased, foreign-registered aircraft to undertake their operations," CAA 
Consumers and Markets Director Paul Smith said.
Smith said using wet-leased aircraft undermines the competitiveness of the UK aviation industry and the 
effectiveness of the regulatory regime.
Price (GBP): £15.46, Change: £-0.87, Percent Change: -5.33%
Load-Date: December 22, 2020
End of Document

Dec 22, 2020( Ticker Report: http://www.tickerreport.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Ryanair Holdings plc (RYA.L) 
(LON:RYA) crossed below its fifty day moving average during trading on Monday . The stock has a fifty day moving 
average of $15.30 and traded as low as $15.04. Ryanair Holdings plc (RYA.L) shares last traded at $15.40, with a 
volume of 1,580,403 shares trading hands. Separately, UBS Group reaffirmed a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair 
Holdings plc (RYA.L) in a research report on Monday, August 24th.The company has a current ratio of 0.87, a quick 
ratio of 0.80 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 112.18. The firm has a market capitalization of 174.91 million and a P/E 
ratio of -18.49. The company has a 50 day simple moving average of GBX 15.30 and a two-hundred day simple 
moving average of GBX 12.54. About Ryanair Holdings plc (RYA.L) (LON:RYA[1])Ryanair Holdings plc, together 
with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, 
Germany, and Other European countries. 
It is also involved in the provision of various ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and internet-
related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation and hotel 
services, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website and mobile app.Featured Article: Correction[2] [ 1]:

4 Airline Stocks Took Off on Vaccine Hopes: Can They Keep Flying in 2021?
4 Airline Stocks Took Off on Vaccine Hopes: Can They Keep Flying in 2021?
Newstex Blogs 
Zacks Investment Research
December 21, 2020 Monday 5:21 PM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1493 words
Byline: Maharathi Basu
Body
Dec 21, 2020( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  The year 2020, which is 
in its last leg, has been anything but fruitful for stocks in the airline space. Agreed that most sectors were hurt by the 
advent of coronavirus, which was declared a pandemic by the World Health Organization in March, the bitter truth is 
that the aviation industry still remains one of the worst-affected areas in the investment world.Passenger revenues, 
which constitute bulk of the top line for the airline companies, have been drastically low do far as air-travel demand 
took a severe beating due to lockdowns and travel restrictions.The sorry state of affairs can be gauged from the 
International Air Transport Association's (IATA) gloomy forecast for 2020. Per the IATA[1], the industry is expected 
to incur a staggering net loss of $118.5 billion in 2020. Passenger revenues are anticipated to be a mere $191 
billion compared with $612 billion recorded in 2019. This gigantic fall in passenger revenues is mainly due to the 
year-over-year anticipated plunge of 66% in overall passenger demand for the current year.Region-wise, North 
American carriers are projected to endure maximum net loss to the tune of $45.8 billion in these coronavirus-
ravaged times with traffic plummeting 66%. European carriers including the likes of Ryanair Holdings RYAAY[2] are 
expected to incur $26.9 billion losses with traffic sinking 70%. Latin American carriers with the likes of Copa 
Holdings CPA[3] and Gol Linhas GOL[4] are projected to lose $5 billion with traffic tanking 60%. Moreover, those in 
the Asia-Pacific area are expected to suffer losses amounting to $31.7 billion in 2020. Carriers in the Middle East 
and Africa are likely to incur losses worth $7.1 billion and $2 billion, respectively, during the current year. 
Vaccine News Buoys Airline Stocks With the pandemic still claiming thousands of lives across the globe, apart from 
infecting many more, multiple medical companies are spending billions on developing an effective vaccine to 
combat the dreaded disease. In this respect, Pfizer PFE[5] and BioNTech's COVID-19 vaccine won the regulatory 
emergency approval in many countries including the UK and the United States after displaying a high degree of 
efficacy in clinical trials. Following this agency nod, vaccination started in the concerned countries.More recently, 
Moderna's vaccine was also okayed by the FDA for emergency use. It goes without saying that the company's 
vaccine was found to be highly effective in its clinical trials. The Moderna vaccine will be shortly administered in the 
United States.In fact, the positive updates on the above vaccines have led the Zacks Airline[6] industry gain 4.7% 
over the past month, outperforming the S&#38;P 500 Index's 3.5% appreciation in the same time period.The 
principal gainers from the airline space during this period were Mesa Air Group MESA[7], American Airlines AAL[8], 
Spirit Airlines SAVE[9] and United Airlines UAL[10], all currently carrying a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). You can seethe 
complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) stocks here[11]. The price performance of the stocks over the 
4 Airline Stocks Took Off on Vaccine Hopes: Can They Keep Flying in 2021?
past month is given in the chart below. Will the Uptick Continue in 2021? The year 2021 is expected to be brighter 
for the airlines in view of the above vaccines and many more in various stages of development. The availability of 
the vaccines is a major boost to the airline companies, which are pinning hopes on people's return to air travel, 
once vaccinated, as there will be no fear of infection looming on. This, in turn, should boost passenger 
revenues.Another encouraging development for the airlines is the agreement reached by the U.S. Congress to 
approve $900 billion for a fresh coronavirus-relief package. The tentative deal inked yesterday comes after months 
of negotiations following the expiry of the CARES Act on Sep 30.The new package includes a $15-billion grant to 
the U.S. airlines toward new payroll assistance, per a BNN Bloomberg report[12]. Notably, carriers like American 
Airlines and United Airlines shrunk their respective workforces due to the suppressed demand scenario following 
the expiry of the CARES Act on Sep 30. Now the new payroll aid allows them to call back the laid-off 
employees.Apart from the upbeat news on the airline jobs front, that 2021 is likely to see an improvement for the 
aviation industry compared to 2020 can be gauged from IATA's bullish forecast. Total loss for the industry is 
envisioned to come down to $38.7 billion next year. IATA anticipates 2.8 billion people taking to the skies in 2021, 
one billion more than the current-year expectation. Load factor (% of seats filled by passengers) is likely to surge to 
72.7% next year from the projection of 65.5% for 2020.Even though passenger revenues are unlikely to return to 
the pre-coronavirus levels in 2021 itself, we expect the stocks in the airline domain to have a much better time next 
year owing to the aforementioned tailwinds. Zacks Top 10 Stocks for 2021 In addition to the stocks discussed 
above, would you like to know about our 10 top tickers for the entirety of 2021?These 10 are painstakingly hand-
picked from over 4,000 companies covered by the Zacks Rank. They are our primary picks to buy and hold. Start 
Your Access to the New Zacks Top 10 Stocks  > >[13]Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment 
Research? Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days. Click to get this free report[14] Ryanair 
Holdings PLC (RYAAY): Free Stock Analysis Report[15] Pfizer Inc. (PFE): Free Stock Analysis Report[16] Gol 
Linhas Aereas Inteligentes S.A. (GOL): Free Stock Analysis Report[17] United Airlines Holdings Inc (UAL): Free 
Stock Analysis Report[18] American Airlines Group Inc. (AAL): Free Stock Analysis Report[19] Copa Holdings, S.A. 
(CPA): Free Stock Analysis Report[20] Spirit Airlines, Inc. (SAVE): Free Stock Analysis Report[21] Mesa Air Group, 
Inc. (MESA): Free Stock Analysis Report[22] To read this article on Zacks.com click here.[23] Zacks Investment

Morgan Stanley Reaffirms 'Overweight' Rating for Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
Morgan Stanley Reaffirms 'Overweight' Rating for Ryanair 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY)
Newstex Blogs 
Watchlist News
December 20, 2020 Sunday 10:30 AM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 721 words
Body
Dec 
20, 
2020( 
Watchlist 
News: 
http://www.watchlistnews.com/ 
Delivered 
by 
Newstex)  
https://www.marketbeat.com/logos/ryanair-holdings-plc-logo.jpgMorgan Stanley reiterated their overweight rating on 
shares of Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) in a research report released on Thursday, The Fly[1] reports. A number of 
other equities research analysts have also issued reports on RYAAY. 
Raymond James increased their target price on shares of Ryanair from $100.00 to $125.00 and gave the stock an 
outperform rating in a report on Wednesday. Deutsche Bank Aktiengesellschaft reiterated a buy rating on shares of 
Ryanair in a report on Friday, December 4th. Liberum Capital lowered shares of Ryanair from a buy rating to a hold 
rating in a report on Monday, September 14th. The Goldman Sachs Group reissued a buy rating on shares of 
Ryanair in a research report on Monday, November 30th. Finally, JPMorgan Chase &#38; Co. reissued an 
overweight rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Friday, November 27th. Two investment analysts 
have rated the stock with a sell rating, seven have assigned a hold rating and eleven have issued a buy rating to 
the stock. Ryanair currently has an average rating of Hold and an average target price of $96.50. Shares of 
NASDAQ RYAAY[2] opened at $109.02 on Thursday. Ryanair has a 12-month low of $44.44 and a 12-month high 
of $118.17. The stock has a market cap of $24.54 billion, a PE ratio of 96.48 and a beta of 1.40. The company has 
a current ratio of 0.67, a quick ratio of 0.67 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.57. The company has a 50-day moving 
average of $102.33 and a 200 day moving average of $84.01.  Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last posted its earnings 
results on Monday, November 2nd. The transportation company reported ($0.12) earnings per share for the quarter, 
beating the consensus estimate of ($0.26) by $0.14. The company had revenue of $1.23 billion for the quarter, 
compared to analyst estimates of $1.17 billion. Ryanair had a net margin of 3.61% and a return on equity of 
10.45%. On average, sell-side analysts forecast that Ryanair will post -5.16 EPS for the current fiscal year. A 
number of hedge funds have recently modified their holdings of the stock. CWM Advisors LLC grew its stake in 
Ryanair by 1.7% during the second quarter. CWM Advisors LLC now owns 10,996 shares of the transportation 
company's stock worth $730,000 after buying an additional 179 shares during the period. PNC Financial Services 
Group Inc. boosted its stake in Ryanair by 23.5% during the 2nd quarter. PNC Financial Services Group Inc. now 
owns 958 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $64,000 after acquiring an additional 182 shares 
during the last quarter. Janney Montgomery Scott LLC boosted its stake in Ryanair by 4.4% during the 3rd quarter. 
Janney Montgomery Scott LLC now owns 4,789 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $392,000 
after acquiring an additional 203 shares during the last quarter. Hexagon Capital Partners LLC bought a new 
position in Ryanair during the 3rd quarter valued at $30,000. Finally, Private Advisor Group LLC bought a new 
Morgan Stanley Reaffirms 'Overweight' Rating for Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
position in Ryanair during the 2nd quarter valued at $25,000. 44.15% of the stock is owned by hedge funds and 
other institutional investors.  About Ryanair Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-
passenger airline services in Ireland, the United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Germany, and Other European countries. It 
is also involved in the provision of various ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and internet-
related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation and hotel 
services, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website and mobile app. See Also: What is a Buy-Side

https://www.marketbeat.com/logos/ryanair-holdings-plc-logo.jpgRyanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) had its price objective 
upped by Raymond James from $100.00 to $125.00 in a research note released on Wednesday, AR Network[1] 
reports. The brokerage currently has an outperform rating on the transportation company's stock.RYAAY has been 
the topic of several other reports. 
Peel Hunt initiated coverage on shares of Ryanair in a report on Tuesday, September 22nd. They issued a sell 
rating on the stock. Wolfe Research initiated coverage on shares of Ryanair in a report on Monday, December 7th. 
They issued a market perform rating on the stock. Barclays restated an overweight rating on shares of Ryanair in a 
report on Monday, October 19th. The Goldman Sachs Group restated a buy rating on shares of Ryanair in a report 
on Monday, November 30th. Finally, AlphaValue upgraded shares of Ryanair to a sell rating in a report on 
Wednesday, December 2nd. Two investment analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, seven have given a 
hold rating and eleven have given a buy rating to the company. The company has an average rating of Hold and a 
consensus target price of $96.50.RYAAY[2] opened at $109.02 on Wednesday. Ryanair has a one year low of

a quick ratio of 0.67. The company's 50 day simple moving average is $102.33 and its 200-day simple moving 
average is $84.01. The stock has a market capitalization of $24.54 billion, a P/E ratio of 96.48 and a beta of 1.40. 
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last released its quarterly earnings results on Monday, November 2nd. The

Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Stock Rating Reaffirmed by Morgan Stanley

Newstex Blogs 
DailyPolitical
December 19, 2020 Saturday 10:05 AM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 731 words
Body
Dec 19, 2020( DailyPolitical: http://www.dailypolitical.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY)'s 
stock had its "overweight" rating restated by research analysts at Morgan Stanley in a research report issued to 
clients and investors on Thursday, The Fly[1] reports.A number of other brokerages also recently commented on 
RYAAY. Liberum Capital downgraded shares of Ryanair from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a research report 
on Monday, September 14th. Wolfe Research assumed coverage on shares of Ryanair in a research note on 
Monday, December 7th. 
They issued a "market perform" rating for the company. Deutsche Bank Aktiengesellschaft restated a "buy" rating 
on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Friday, December 4th. AlphaValue upgraded shares of Ryanair to a 
"sell" rating in a research report on Wednesday, December 2nd. Finally, BidaskClub cut shares of Ryanair from a 
"buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a research report on Tuesday, September 29th. Two research analysts have rated 
the stock with a sell rating, seven have issued a hold rating and eleven have given a buy rating to the company. 
The stock presently has an average rating of "Hold" and an average price target of $96.50.Ryanair stock[2] opened 
at $109.02 on Thursday. The company has a market cap of $24.54 billion, a P/E ratio of 96.48 and a beta of 1.40.

average of $102.33 and a 200 day simple moving average of $84.01. The company has a current ratio of 0.67, a 
quick ratio of 0.67 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.57. Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last released its earnings results 
on Monday, November 2nd. The transportation company reported ($0.12) earnings per share for the quarter, 
beating analysts' consensus estimates of ($0.26) by $0.14. The business had revenue of $1.23 billion during the 
quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $1.17 billion. Ryanair had a net margin of 3.61% and a return on 
equity of 10.45%. On average, equities research analysts forecast that Ryanair will post -5.16 EPS for the current 
year. Several large investors have recently bought and sold shares of RYAAY. FMR LLC lifted its position in shares

State Street Corp Purchases 37,228 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
State Street Corp Purchases 37,228 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
December 18, 2020 Friday
Copyright 2020 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 655 words
Body
Ryanair logo State Street Corp grew its position in shares of  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 58.0% in 
the 3rd quarter, according to the company in its most recent 13F filing with the SEC. The fund owned 101,380 
shares of the transportation company's stock after purchasing an additional 37,228 shares during the quarter. State 
Street Corp's holdings in Ryanair were worth $8,289,000 as of its most recent SEC filing.  
Other institutional investors have also recently added to or reduced their stakes in the company. Private Advisor 
Group LLC bought a new stake in shares of  Ryanair in the 2nd quarter valued at $25,000.  Rockefeller Capital 
Management L.P. boosted its holdings in  Ryanair by 239.7% during the 2nd quarter. Rockefeller Capital 
Management L.P. now owns 822 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $55,000 after acquiring an 
additional 580 shares during the last quarter.  Pacer Advisors Inc. purchased a new position in  Ryanair during the 
3rd quarter worth $77,000.  PNC Financial Services Group Inc. boosted its holdings in  Ryanair by 23.5% during the 
2nd quarter. PNC Financial Services Group Inc. now owns 958 shares of the transportation company's stock worth 
$64,000 after acquiring an additional 182 shares during the last quarter.  Finally, Rockbridge Investment 
Management LCC purchased a new position in  Ryanair during the 3rd quarter worth $113,000. Hedge funds and 
other institutional investors own  44.15% of the company's stock.  
Shares of Ryanair stock  opened at $108.65 on Friday. The company has a quick ratio of 0.67, a current ratio of 
0.67 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.57. The company has a market cap of $24.45 billion, a PE ratio of 96.15 and a 
beta of 1.40. The business has a 50 day moving average of $101.76 and a 200 day moving average of $83.82. 
Ryanair Holdings plc has a 52 week low of $44.44 and a 52 week high of $118.17.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last announced its earnings results on Monday, November 2nd. The transportation 
company reported ($0.12) EPS for the quarter, beating analysts' consensus estimates of ($0.26) by $0.14. The 
company had revenue of $1.23 billion during the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $1.17 billion. 
Ryanair had a return on equity of 10.45% and a net margin of 3.61%.  On average, research analysts anticipate that  
Ryanair Holdings plc will post -5.16 earnings per share for the current year.  
A number of equities analysts recently weighed in on RYAAY shares. Raymond James boosted their price target on 
shares of Ryanair from $100.00 to $125.00 and gave the stock an "outperform" rating in a report on Wednesday. 
Deutsche Bank Aktiengesellschaft  reissued a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair in a report on Friday, December 
4th. ValuEngine  raised shares of Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a report on Thursday, October 1st. 
UBS Group  reissued a "neutral" rating on shares of Ryanair in a report on Monday, December 7th. Finally, Credit 
State Street Corp Purchases 37,228 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
Suisse Group  restated an "outperform" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research note on Tuesday, November 10th. 
Two investment analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, seven have issued  a hold rating and eleven have 
issued  a buy rating to the stock. Ryanair presently has an average rating of "Hold" and an average price target of 
$96.50. 
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Germany, and Other European countries. It is also involved in the provision of various 
ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, 
food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation and hotel services, car hire, and travel insurance through its 
Website and mobile app.

Ryanair logo Truist Financial Corp cut its stake in shares of  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 11.2% in 
the third quarter, according to its most recent disclosure with the SEC. The firm owned 14,896 shares of the 
transportation company's stock after selling 1,872 shares during the period. Truist Financial Corp's holdings in 
Ryanair were worth $1,217,000 at the end of the most recent quarter.  
Other large investors also recently bought and sold shares of the company. Altium Wealth Management LLC raised 
its position in  Ryanair by 12.1% during the third quarter. Altium Wealth Management LLC now owns 7,441 shares 
of the transportation company's stock worth $608,000 after acquiring an additional 803 shares during the period.

Massachusetts Financial Services Co. MA now owns 8,822,089 shares of the transportation company's stock 
valued at $721,295,000 after buying an additional 316,925 shares during the last quarter.  Adelphi Capital LLP 
raised its position in shares of  Ryanair by 9.8% in the third quarter. Adelphi Capital LLP now owns 1,198,344 
shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $97,977,000 after buying an additional 107,444 shares 
during the last quarter.  Virtu Financial LLC acquired a new stake in shares of  Ryanair in the second quarter valued 
at about $582,000.  Finally, Standard Life Aberdeen plc raised its position in shares of  Ryanair by 78.3% in the 
third quarter. Standard Life Aberdeen plc now owns 80,701 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at 
$6,601,000 after buying an additional 35,429 shares during the last quarter. Institutional investors own  44.15% of 
the company's stock.  
A number of equities research analysts have recently commented on the stock. ValuEngine  upgraded shares of 
Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a research report on Thursday, October 1st. JPMorgan Chase & Co.  
reissued an "overweight" rating on shares of Ryanair in a report on Friday, November 27th. Raymond James upped 
their price objective on shares of Ryanair from $100.00 to $125.00 and gave the company an "outperform" rating in 
a report on Wednesday. Deutsche Bank Aktiengesellschaft  reissued a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair in a report 
on Friday, December 4th. Finally, Barclays  reissued an "overweight" rating on shares of Ryanair in a report on 
Monday, October 19th. Two analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, seven have assigned  a hold rating and 
eleven have issued  a buy rating to the company's stock. Ryanair  has a consensus rating of "Hold" and a 
consensus target price of $96.50. 
Shares of RYAAY  opened at $106.31 on Thursday. The stock has a market capitalization of $23.93 billion, a PE 
ratio of 94.08 and a beta of 1.40. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 1 year low of $44.44 and a 1 year high of $118.17. 
Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Shares Sold by Truist Financial Corp
The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.57, a quick ratio of 0.67 and a current ratio of 0.67. The company's 50-
day simple moving average is $101.29 and its 200-day simple moving average is $83.65.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last issued its quarterly earnings results on Monday, November 2nd. The transportation 
company reported ($0.12) earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, topping the Thomson Reuters' consensus 
estimate of ($0.26) by $0.14. The business had revenue of $1.23 billion for the quarter, compared to analysts' 
expectations of $1.17 billion. Ryanair had a net margin of 3.61% and a return on equity of 10.45%.  On average, 
sell-side analysts predict that  Ryanair Holdings plc will post -5.16 earnings per share for the current year.  
Ryanair Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Germany, and Other European countries. It is also involved in the provision of various 
ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, 
food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation and hotel services, car hire, and travel insurance through its 
Website and mobile app.

high of $118.17. The stock's 50 day moving average is $101.29 and its 200-day moving average is $83.65. The 
company has a current ratio of 0.67, a quick ratio of 0.67 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.57. The company has a 
market capitalization of $23.93 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 94.08 and a beta of 1.40.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last issued its quarterly earnings results on Monday, November 2nd. The transportation 
company reported ($0.12) earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, topping the Zacks' consensus estimate of 
($0.26) by $0.14. The business had revenue of $1.23 billion for the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of 
$1.17 billion. Ryanair had a return on equity of 10.45% and a net margin of 3.61%.  As a group, equities research 
analysts predict that  Ryanair Holdings plc will post -5.16 earnings per share for the current fiscal year.  
Ryanair Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Germany, and Other European countries. It is also involved in the provision of various 
ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, 
food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation and hotel services, car hire, and travel insurance through its 
Website and mobile app.

Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Receives Overweight Rating from Morgan Stanley
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Receives Overweight Rating from Morgan 
Stanley
American Banking and Market News
December 17, 2020 Thursday
Copyright 2020 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 677 words
Body
Ryanair logo Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY)'s stock had its "overweight" rating reissued by equities researchers at 
Morgan Stanley in a research report issued to clients and investors on Thursday, The Fly  reports. 
A number of other brokerages have also weighed in on RYAAY. Peel Hunt started coverage on shares of Ryanair in 
a report on Tuesday, September 22nd. They issued a "sell" rating for the company. Barclays  reissued an 
"overweight" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research note on Monday, October 19th. ValuEngine  raised Ryanair 
from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a research note on Thursday, October 1st. Liberum Capital lowered shares 
of Ryanair from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a report on Monday, September 14th. Finally, JPMorgan Chase & 
Co.  restated an "overweight" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Friday, November 27th. Two 
analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, seven have given a hold rating and eleven have assigned  a buy 
rating to the company. The stock  has an average rating of "Hold" and a consensus target price of $96.50. 
Shares of RYAAY stock  traded up $0.90 during trading hours on Thursday, hitting $107.21. The company had a 
trading volume of 6,501 shares, compared to its average volume of 687,372. Ryanair has a 12 month low of $44.44 
and a 12 month high of $118.17. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.57, a quick ratio of 0.67 and a current 
ratio of 0.67. The firm's fifty day moving average is $101.29 and its 200 day moving average is $83.65. The firm has 
a market capitalization of $24.13 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 94.88 and a beta of 1.40.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last released its quarterly earnings results on Monday, November 2nd. The 
transportation company reported ($0.12) EPS for the quarter, beating the Zacks' consensus estimate of ($0.26) by 
$0.14. The firm had revenue of $1.23 billion for the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $1.17 billion. Ryanair 
had a net margin of 3.61% and a return on equity of 10.45%.  On average, sell-side analysts expect that  Ryanair 
will post -5.16 EPS for the current fiscal year.  
Several large investors have recently added to or reduced their stakes in RYAAY. BlackRock Fund Advisors grew 
its position in shares of  Ryanair by 11.9% during the first quarter. BlackRock Fund Advisors now owns 681,930 
shares of the transportation company's stock worth $58,523,000 after acquiring an additional 72,455 shares during 
the last quarter.  BB&T Corp raised its position in  Ryanair by 38.1% during the 2nd quarter. BB&T Corp now owns 
6,103 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $391,000 after buying an additional 1,684 shares during 
the last quarter.  Altium Wealth Management LLC grew its stake in  Ryanair by 12.1% in the 3rd quarter. Altium 
Wealth Management LLC now owns 7,441 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $608,000 after 
acquiring an additional 803 shares during the last quarter.  Capital Fund Management S.A. raised its holdings in  
Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Receives Overweight Rating from Morgan Stanley
Ryanair by 1,356.3% in the 2nd quarter. Capital Fund Management S.A. now owns 148,685 shares of the 
transportation company's stock valued at $10,340,000 after acquiring an additional 138,475 shares during the last 
quarter.  Finally, George Kaiser Family Foundation purchased a new stake in  Ryanair during the fourth quarter 
valued at about $1,160,000. 44.15% of the stock is currently owned by institutional investors and hedge funds.  
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Germany, and Other European countries. It is also involved in the provision of various 
ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, 
food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation and hotel services, car hire, and travel insurance through its 
Website and mobile app.

Norwegian Air woes reveal hazy status of corporate nationality INSIDE BUSINESS EUROPE
Norwegian Air woes reveal hazy status of corporate nationality; INSIDE 
BUSINESS EUROPE
Financial Times (London, England)
December 17, 2020 Thursday
Edition 1, European Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 6
Length: 768 words
Byline: Richard Milne
Body
How Irish is Norwegian Air Shuttle? An Irish judge wanted to know last week. Enough to grant protection from 
creditors, it seems. A few weeks earlier the Norwegian government was asking the low-cost airline how Norwegian 
it really was. Not enough to get a second bailout was the government's conclusion.
The nationality of a company can often seem unimportant. Businesses are founded in one country, move to a 
second and can list on the stock exchange in a third, all while their main business could be in a fourth.
But as Norwegian and others have discovered in recent months, when things go badly, nationality can suddenly 
become very important.
The airline started life almost three decades ago as a regional Norwegian carrier. It was in this country that it took 
steps first to become a low-cost challenger to SAS in Scandinavia and then a rival to Ryanair and easyJet in much 
of the rest of Europe.
High-cost, heavily unionised Norway does not seem the ideal country from which to launch a low-cost airline. And 
so it proved, as Norwegian set up subsidiaries in Ireland for operations and aircraft financing and also in UK for 
operations, as well as countries such as Spain, Denmark and Sweden for staffing.
Norwegian Air woes reveal hazy status of corporate nationality INSIDE BUSINESS EUROPE
Hubris then appeared to strike. It started regional flights in Argentina at the same time as it tried to crack the 
lucrative transatlantic market, something no low-cost carrier had ever managed. Soon, rivals, analysts and bankers 
were forecasting a humbling as its rapid expansion led to an equally rapid growth in debt.
Norwegian entered the Covid-19 pandemic as one of the most heavily leveraged of large airlines in Europe and, 
despite a first, limited bailout from Oslo, it was clear that surviving this winter was going to be an almighty 
challenge.
Norwegian is undoubtedly an important airline in Norway and many away from Oslo remember the days of an SAS 
monopoly and the high ticket prices that came with that. But Norwegian politicians were hesitant to back it further, 
worrying not just over its high debt load but also whet- her it was sufficiently Norwegian.
'Very little has Norwegian in few years. Do support them they are called "I feel like they have the name, but very 
little else has been Norwegian in the past few years. The crew are Danish or Spanish or British. Do we have to 
support them just because they are called Norwegian?" one opposition politician told me this autumn.
The government concluded no. Weeks later though, Irish judge Michael Quinn was asking Norwegian to justify its 
Irish nature. Lawyers for the airline pointed to bases in the country for both Norwegian Air International, which it 
used for flights from the UK and Ireland to the US, and Arctic Aviation Asset, the group's financing arm. The judge 
was satisfied, and the Irish equivalent of Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection was unleashed. A day later, the 
company filed for a reconstruction under Norwegian law as well.
It is not just Norwegian that has confused nationality in the Nordics. Ikea is often described as a Swedish retailer.
But its two main headquarters have not been in Sweden for more than four decades, even if it retains a strong 
presence there. They moved first to Denmark, and then the Netherlands. The two main parts of the flat-pack 
furniture empire are based in Leiden and Delft, and owned by Dutch and Liechtenstein foundations. Tax clearly 
played a role, but so did the demand of founder Ingvar Kamprad that they be protected from takeover and banks, 
hence the foundation owners designed to give Ikea "eternal life".
Does it matter to those that buy meatballs in stores clad in the colours of the Swedish flag or to people flying in 
planes with Thor Heyerdahl or Roald Dahl on the tail fins? Perhaps not, but it may surprise them and, at the 
margins, affect their view of the brand and its desirability.
Still, companies have to be aware of the downsides of being too rootless, especially when times are tough. The 
centre-left Norwegian politician said: "Theresa May [former UK prime minister] talked of citizens of nowhere; I'm 
worried some companies are like that."
Norwegian has now bought itself time through the tricky winter season to try to restructure its debts and sell some 
aircraft in the hope of becoming a leaner, more viable airline. Meanwhile, for those in Norway worried that not 
backing Norwegian could lead to less competition, help has arrived. Hungary's Wizz Air is offering flights between 
Oslo and Tromso at an even lower price.
richard.milne@ft.com
'Very little has been Norwegian in the past few years. Do we have to support them just because they are called 
Norwegian?'
Load-Date: December 16, 2020
End of Document

centre-left Norwegian politician said: "Theresa May [former UK prime minister] talked of citizens of nowhere; I'm

Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) and Spirit Airlines ( NYSE :SAVE) Head to Head Review
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) and Spirit Airlines (NYSE:SAVE) Head to Head 
Review
Newstex Blogs 
Zolmax.com
December 17, 2020 Thursday 10:06 AM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 672 words
Body
Dec 17, 2020( Zolmax.com: http://www.zolmax.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Spirit Airlines (NYSE:SAVE[1]) and 
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY[2]) are both transportation companies, but which is the better stock? We will compare 
the two companies based on the strength of their valuation, profitability, earnings, risk, analyst recommendations, 
institutional ownership and dividends. ProfitabilityThis table compares Spirit Airlines and Ryanair's net margins, 
return on equity and return on assets. 
Analyst RatingsThis is a summary of current ratings and target prices for Spirit Airlines and Ryanair, as reported by 
MarketBeat.com.  Spirit Airlines presently has a consensus price target of $27.50, indicating a potential upside of 
5.12%. Ryanair has a consensus price target of $125.00, indicating a potential upside of 17.58%. Given Ryanair's 
stronger consensus rating and higher probable upside, analysts clearly believe Ryanair is more favorable than Spirit 
Airlines. Earnings &#38; Valuation This table compares Spirit Airlines and Ryanair's revenue, earnings per share 
and valuation. Ryanair has higher revenue and earnings than Spirit Airlines. Spirit Airlines is trading at a lower 
price-to-earnings ratio than Ryanair, indicating that it is currently the more affordable of the two stocks. Insider and 
Institutional Ownership54.4% of Spirit Airlines shares are owned by institutional investors. Comparatively, 44.2% of 
Ryanair shares are owned by institutional investors. 0.6% of Spirit Airlines shares are owned by company insiders. 
Strong institutional ownership is an indication that hedge funds, large money managers and endowments believe a 
company will outperform the market over the long term.Volatility and Risk Spirit Airlines has a beta of 1.27, 
suggesting that its stock price is 27% more volatile than the S&#38;P 500. Comparatively, Ryanair has a beta of 
1.4, suggesting that its stock price is 40% more volatile than the S&#38;P 500. SummaryRyanair beats Spirit 
Airlines on 10 of the 14 factors compared between the two stocks.Spirit Airlines Company ProfileSpirit Airlines, Inc. 
provides low-fare airline services. The company operates approximately 600 daily flights to 77 destinations in the 
United States, the Caribbean, and Latin America. As of December 31, 2019, the company had a fleet of 145 Airbus 
single-aisle aircraft comprising 31 A319ceos, 64 A320ceos, 20 A320neos and 30 A321ceos. It offers tickets through 
its call centers and airport ticket counters, as well as online through spirit.com; and through various third parties, 
including online, traditional travel agents, and electronic global distribution systems. The company was formerly 
known as Clippert Trucking Company and changed its name to Spirit Airlines, Inc. in 1992. Spirit Airlines, Inc. was 
founded in 1964 and is headquartered in Miramar, Florida.Ryanair Company ProfileRyanair Holdings plc, together 
with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, 
Germany, and Other European countries. It is also involved in the provision of various ancillary services, such as 
non-flight scheduled services and internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and merchandise; and 
Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) and Spirit Airlines ( NYSE :SAVE) Head to Head Review
marketing accommodation and hotel services, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website and mobile app. In 
addition, the company offers aircraft and passenger handling, ticketing, marketing and advertising, and 
maintenance and repair services; and markets car parking, attractions, and activities on its website and mobile app, 
as well as sells gift vouchers. As of June 30, 2020, it had a principal fleet of approximately 440 Boeing 737 aircraft 
and 26 Airbus A320 aircraft; and offered approximately 2,500 scheduled short-haul flights per day serving 
approximately 242 airports, including 79 bases. Ryanair Holdings plc was founded in 1985 and is headquartered in 
Swords, 
Ireland.

Morgan Stanley Trims Position in Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY)
Morgan Stanley Trims Position in Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
December 16, 2020 Wednesday
Copyright 2020 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 667 words
Body
Ryanair logo Morgan Stanley cut its holdings in shares of  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 5.5% during 
the 3rd quarter, according to its most recent Form 13F filing with the SEC. The firm owned 335,332 shares of the 
transportation company's stock after selling 19,627 shares during the period. Morgan Stanley owned 0.15% of 
Ryanair worth $27,416,000 as of its most recent SEC filing.  
Several other institutional investors and hedge funds have also bought and sold shares of the company. CWM 
Advisors LLC grew its stake in  Ryanair by 1.7% in the second quarter. CWM Advisors LLC now owns 10,996 
shares of the transportation company's stock worth $730,000 after purchasing an additional 179 shares during the 
period.  PNC Financial Services Group Inc. grew its stake in  Ryanair by 23.5% in the second quarter. PNC 
Financial Services Group Inc. now owns 958 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $64,000 after 
purchasing an additional 182 shares during the period.  Janney Montgomery Scott LLC grew its stake in  Ryanair by 
4.4% in the third quarter. Janney Montgomery Scott LLC now owns 4,789 shares of the transportation company's 
stock worth $392,000 after purchasing an additional 203 shares during the period.  Hexagon Capital Partners LLC 
purchased a new stake in  Ryanair in the third quarter worth $30,000.  Finally, Private Advisor Group LLC 
purchased a new stake in  Ryanair in the second quarter worth $25,000. 44.15% of the stock is currently owned by 
hedge funds and other institutional investors.  
Shares of NASDAQ RYAAY  opened at $105.85 on Wednesday. The firm's 50-day moving average price is 
$100.91 and its 200-day moving average price is $83.48. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 52-week low of $44.44 and a 
52-week high of $118.17. The company has a market cap of $23.82 billion, a PE ratio of 93.67 and a beta of 1.40. 
The company has a quick ratio of 0.67, a current ratio of 0.67 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.57.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last released its quarterly earnings data on Monday, November 2nd. The transportation 
company reported ($0.12) earnings per share for the quarter, beating the consensus estimate of ($0.26) by $0.14. 
Ryanair had a net margin of 3.61% and a return on equity of 10.45%. The firm had revenue of $1.23 billion during 
the quarter, compared to analysts' expectations of $1.17 billion.  As a group, equities research analysts anticipate 
that  Ryanair Holdings plc will post -5.16 EPS for the current fiscal year.  
RYAAY has been the topic of several recent research reports. Credit Suisse Group  reaffirmed an "outperform" 
rating on shares of Ryanair in a research note on Tuesday, November 10th. Raymond James upped their price 
target on Ryanair from $90.00 to $100.00 and gave the stock an "outperform" rating in a research note on 
Wednesday, October 7th. Deutsche Bank Aktiengesellschaft  reissued a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair in a 
research note on Friday, December 4th. Morgan Stanley  reissued an "overweight" rating on shares of Ryanair in a 
Morgan Stanley Trims Position in Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY)
research note on Tuesday, November 3rd. Finally, Barclays  reissued an "overweight" rating on shares of Ryanair 
in a research note on Monday, October 19th. Two analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, seven have given 
a hold rating and eleven have assigned  a buy rating to the stock. The stock  has a consensus rating of "Hold" and 
an average target price of $84.00. 
Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Germany, and Other European countries. It is also involved in the provision of various 
ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, 
food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation and hotel services, car hire, and travel insurance through its 
Website and mobile app.

Raymond James Raises Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Price Target to $125.00
Raymond James Raises Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Price Target to $125.00
American Banking and Market News
December 16, 2020 Wednesday
Copyright 2020 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 712 words
Body
Ryanair logo Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) had its price target raised by equities researchers at Raymond James  
from $100.00 to $125.00 in a research report issued on Wednesday, Benzinga  reports. The brokerage presently 
has an "outperform" rating on the transportation company's stock. Raymond James' price target would indicate a 
potential upside of 18.09% from the stock's current price. 
Other equities research analysts also recently issued reports about the stock. Wolfe Research started coverage on 
shares of Ryanair in a research report on Monday, December 7th. They issued a "market perform" rating for the 
company. BidaskClub downgraded Ryanair from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a research note on Tuesday, 
September 29th. ValuEngine  upgraded Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a research note on 
Thursday, October 1st. Credit Suisse Group  reissued an "outperform" rating on shares of Ryanair in a report on 
Tuesday, November 10th. Finally, UBS Group  restated a "neutral" rating on shares of Ryanair in a report on 
Monday, December 7th. Two equities research analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, seven have issued  
a hold rating and eleven have assigned  a buy rating to the stock. The stock  has an average rating of "Hold" and an 
average price target of $96.50. 
Shares of NASDAQ RYAAY  opened at $105.85 on Wednesday. The company has a quick ratio of 0.67, a current 
ratio of 0.67 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.57. The firm has a market cap of $23.82 billion, a PE ratio of 93.67 and a 
beta of 1.40. The company's fifty day simple moving average is $100.91 and its 200 day simple moving average is 
$83.48. Ryanair has a 12-month low of $44.44 and a 12-month high of $118.17.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last issued its earnings results on Monday, November 2nd. The transportation 
company reported ($0.12) EPS for the quarter, beating analysts' consensus estimates of ($0.26) by $0.14. Ryanair 
had a return on equity of 10.45% and a net margin of 3.61%. The business had revenue of $1.23 billion during the 
quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $1.17 billion.  On average, equities analysts predict that  Ryanair will post 
-5.16 earnings per share for the current year.  
A number of large investors have recently bought and sold shares of RYAAY. BB&T Securities lifted its position in  
Ryanair by 1.6% during the fourth quarter. BB&T Securities now owns 11,630 shares of the transportation 
company's stock valued at $1,005,000 after purchasing an additional 185 shares during the last quarter.  Adelphi 
Capital lifted its holdings in shares of  Ryanair by 3.5% during the 4th quarter. Adelphi Capital now owns 132,371 
shares of the transportation company's stock worth $11,444,000 after acquiring an additional 4,455 shares during 
the last quarter.  Ferguson Wellman Capital Management Inc. grew its position in  Ryanair by 2.0% in the fourth 
quarter. Ferguson Wellman Capital Management Inc. now owns 71,362 shares of the transportation company's 
Raymond James Raises Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Price Target to $125.00
stock worth $6,170,000 after acquiring an additional 1,389 shares in the last quarter.  Russell Frank Co increased 
its stake in  Ryanair by 408.9% in the fourth quarter. Russell Frank Co now owns 690,664 shares of the 
transportation company's stock valued at $60,060,000 after acquiring an additional 554,940 shares during the last

after purchasing an additional 739 shares in the last quarter. 44.15% of the stock is owned by institutional investors.

institutional investor  owned 8,286 shares of the transportation company's stock after purchasing an additional

recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC).

quarter. Institutional investors and hedge funds own  44.15% of the company's stock.

System for testing travellers overwhelmed on first day; Private providers
System for testing travellers overwhelmed on first day; Private providers
Financial Times (London, England)
December 16, 2020 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 3
Length: 447 words
Byline: JIM PICKARD; PHILIP GEORGIADIS; ANNA GROSS
Body
The government's new system of private coronavirus testing to allow travellers to slash quarantine from 10 to five 
days was in chaos within hours of its launch yesterday.
Many of the 12 providers approved by the government admitted they had run out of tests, some websites crashed 
and others were not yet ready to receive bookings.
The "test and release" scheme for travellers was announced last month and was welcomed by airlines as a way to 
encourage travel by halving the amount of time people have to selfisolate after entering England.
But the approved providers were left struggling on the first day of the programme when passengers tried to access 
more information through the transport department website.
SameDayDoctor and The Private GP Clinic, two of the companies, advised people that they were unable to offer 
tests for returning travellers, and were replaced with other companies.
"Unfortunately, we have been so overwhelmed with requests for test and release that we cannot answer any more 
emails nor take any more bookings," SameDayDoctor said.
A link to one provider, Oncologica, diverted people to another called Screen4, whose website crashed in the 
morning - although both sites were running later in the day. The website of Medicspot said tests were not yet 
available to be booked.
System for testing travellers overwhelmed on first day; Private providers
The London General Practice, also on the list, said its website was "currently under maintenance", although it was 
taking bookings by telephone.
Halo Verify said on its website it was offering test kits for £89 before clarifying that they were out of stock. It was 
instead accepting bookings by phone.
Rupert Channing, senior commercial adviser at testing provider Chronomics, said that since the scheme went live, 
demand had been significantly above expectations set out by government.
"Even the most optimistic guide they gave us, this is way outside it," he said. "By 10pm, we had over 3,500 pre-
orders. This morning it has been at that level and higher." He described the line-up of mostly small and unknown 
test providers as "surprising". "It's like a flotilla of small ships," he said.
Michael O'Leary, Ryanair's chief executive, told the Financial Times he was not surprised by the problems with the 
testing system. "[The government] promised a world-class test and tracing system. All they have delivered is 
worldclass incompetence," he said.
The government said the companies approved were required to meet minimum standards that were higher than 
those recommended for general testing of the population, such as for private sector workforces. Ministers were 
planning to certify larger testing providers who were likely to have greater capacity, one aviation industry executive 
said.
Load-Date: December 15, 2020
End of Document

Weekly Investment Analysts' Ratings Changes for Ryanair (RYAAY)

December 14, 2020 Monday
Copyright 2020 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 686 words
Body
Ryanair logo A number of firms have modified their ratings and price targets on shares of Ryanair (NASDAQ: 
RYAAY) recently: 
•
12/7/2020 - Ryanair  had its "neutral" rating reaffirmed by analysts at UBS Group AG.
•
12/7/2020 - Ryanair  is now covered by analysts at Wolfe Research. They set a "market perform" rating on 
the stock.
•
12/4/2020 - Ryanair  had its "buy" rating reaffirmed by analysts at Deutsche Bank Aktiengesellschaft.
•
12/2/2020 - Ryanair  was upgraded by analysts at AlphaValue to a "sell" rating.
•
11/30/2020 - Ryanair  had its "buy" rating reaffirmed by analysts at The Goldman Sachs Group, Inc..
•
11/27/2020 - Ryanair  had its "overweight" rating reaffirmed by analysts at JPMorgan Chase & Co..
•
11/12/2020 - Ryanair  was downgraded by analysts at UBS Group AG from a "buy" rating to a "neutral" 
rating.
•
11/10/2020 - Ryanair  had its "outperform" rating reaffirmed by analysts at Credit Suisse Group AG.
•
11/3/2020 - Ryanair  had its "overweight" rating reaffirmed by analysts at Morgan Stanley.
•
10/19/2020 - Ryanair  had its "overweight" rating reaffirmed by analysts at Barclays PLC.
RYAAY  opened at $106.91 on Monday. The company has a market cap of $24.06 billion, a P/E ratio of 94.61 and 
a beta of 1.40. The business's 50-day moving average price is $99.52 and its 200-day moving average price is 
$82.73. The company has a current ratio of 0.67, a quick ratio of 0.67 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.57. Ryanair 
Holdings plc has a 12 month low of $44.44 and a 12 month high of $118.17.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last released its quarterly earnings data on Monday, November 2nd. The transportation 
company reported ($0.12) EPS for the quarter, topping the Thomson Reuters' consensus estimate of ($0.26) by 
$0.14. The firm had revenue of $1.23 billion for the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $1.17 billion. 
Ryanair had a return on equity of 10.45% and a net margin of 3.61%.  Equities research analysts forecast that  
Ryanair Holdings plc will post -5.16 earnings per share for the current fiscal year.  
A number of large investors have recently made changes to their positions in the stock. Massachusetts Financial 
Services Co. MA increased its holdings in  Ryanair by 3.7% during the 3rd quarter. Massachusetts Financial 
Services Co. MA now owns 8,822,089 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $721,295,000 after

purchasing an additional 316,925 shares during the period.  FMR LLC boosted its position in  Ryanair by 30.9% 
during the 2nd quarter. FMR LLC now owns 5,276,515 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at 
$350,045,000 after acquiring an additional 1,246,442 shares in the last quarter.  Sprucegrove Investment

Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Germany, and Other European countries. It is also involved in the provision of various 
ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, 
food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation and hotel services, car hire, and travel insurance through its 
Website and mobile app.

Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Shares Sold by Sei Investments Co.
Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Shares Sold by Sei Investments Co.
American Banking and Market News
December 14, 2020 Monday
Copyright 2020 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 711 words
Body
Ryanair logo Sei Investments Co. decreased its holdings in  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 13.3% in 
the 3rd quarter, according to the company in its most recent Form 13F filing with the SEC. The firm owned 527,213 
shares of the transportation company's stock after selling 81,168 shares during the quarter. Sei Investments Co. 
owned 0.23% of Ryanair worth $43,081,000 at the end of the most recent reporting period.  
Other hedge funds and other institutional investors have also bought and sold shares of the company. CWM 
Advisors LLC increased its holdings in shares of  Ryanair by 1.7% in the 2nd quarter. CWM Advisors LLC now 
owns 10,996 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $730,000 after acquiring an additional 179 
shares during the period.  PNC Financial Services Group Inc. increased its holdings in shares of  Ryanair by 23.5% 
in the 2nd quarter. PNC Financial Services Group Inc. now owns 958 shares of the transportation company's stock 
valued at $64,000 after acquiring an additional 182 shares during the period.  Janney Montgomery Scott LLC 
increased its holdings in shares of  Ryanair by 4.4% in the 3rd quarter. Janney Montgomery Scott LLC now owns 
4,789 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $392,000 after acquiring an additional 203 shares 
during the period.  Hexagon Capital Partners LLC acquired a new position in shares of  Ryanair in the 3rd quarter 
valued at $30,000.  Finally, Private Advisor Group LLC acquired a new position in shares of  Ryanair in the 2nd 
quarter valued at $25,000. 44.15% of the stock is owned by institutional investors and hedge funds.  
Several brokerages have issued reports on RYAAY. Wolfe Research began coverage on shares of Ryanair in a 
research note on Monday, December 7th. They issued a "market perform" rating on the stock. AlphaValue raised 
shares of Ryanair to a "sell" rating in a research note on Wednesday, December 2nd. Barclays  reissued an 
"overweight" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research note on Monday, October 19th. ValuEngine  raised shares of 
Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a research note on Thursday, October 1st. Finally, JPMorgan Chase 
& Co.  restated an "overweight" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Friday, November 27th. Two 
research analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, seven have assigned  a hold rating and eleven have given 
a buy rating to the company. The company presently has a consensus rating of "Hold" and an average target price 
of $84.00. 
Ryanair stock  opened at $106.91 on Monday. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 52 week low of $44.44 and a 52 week 
high of $118.17. The company has a quick ratio of 0.67, a current ratio of 0.67 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.57. 
The firm's 50-day simple moving average is $99.52 and its 200 day simple moving average is $82.73. The firm has 
a market capitalization of $24.06 billion, a PE ratio of 94.61 and a beta of 1.40.  
Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Shares Sold by Sei Investments Co.
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last released its earnings results on Monday, November 2nd. The transportation 
company reported ($0.12) earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, beating the Zacks' consensus estimate of 
($0.26) by $0.14. The company had revenue of $1.23 billion for the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $1.17 
billion. Ryanair had a net margin of 3.61% and a return on equity of 10.45%.  On average, research analysts expect 
that  Ryanair Holdings plc will post -5.16 EPS for the current fiscal year.  
Ryanair Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Germany, and Other European countries. It is also involved in the provision of various 
ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, 
food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation and hotel services, car hire, and travel insurance through its 
Website and mobile app.
