ASL Airlines France adds maiden B737-800(BCF)
ASL Airlines France adds maiden B737-800(BCF)
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
December 04, 2020
Copyright 2020 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business News; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 214 words
Body
ASL Airlines France (5O, Paris CDG) took delivery of its first B737-800(BCF) in the form of F-HIQB (msn 33641) on 
November 28, 2020. The ex-Pegasus Airlines and ex-Ryanair Boeing narrowbody was ferried after conversion at 
Taikoo (Shandong) Aircraft Engineering Co. Ltd.'s Jinan facility to Paris CDG via Ekaterinburg and Vilnius. The 
13.7-year-old aircraft is owned by ASL Airlines France's parent ASL Aviation Holdings. It has yet to be deployed 
into revenue service. It will join ASL Airlines France's cargo fleet of one B737-300(F), two B737-300(QC)s, and 
seven B737-400(F)s. According to the ch-aviation fleets advanced module, the airline also operates six B737-700s 
and two B737-800s in passenger configurations. Sister carriers ASL Airlines Ireland (ABR, Dublin Int'l) and ASL 
Airlines Belgium (3V, Liège) operate two B737-800(BCF)s each, although the aircraft are not owned by ASL 
Aviation Holdings but rather dry-leased from GECAS.

across

End of Document
ASL Airlines France adds maiden B737-800(BCF)
ASL Airlines France adds maiden B737-800(BCF)
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
December 04, 2020
Copyright 2020 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business News and Features; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 214 words
Body
ASL Airlines France (5O, Paris CDG) took delivery of its first B737-800(BCF) in the form of F-HIQB (msn 33641) on 
November 28, 2020. The ex-Pegasus Airlines and ex-Ryanair Boeing narrowbody was ferried after conversion at 
Taikoo (Shandong) Aircraft Engineering Co. Ltd.'s Jinan facility to Paris CDG via Ekaterinburg and Vilnius. The 
13.7-year-old aircraft is owned by ASL Airlines France's parent ASL Aviation Holdings. It has yet to be deployed 
into revenue service. It will join ASL Airlines France's cargo fleet of one B737-300(F), two B737-300(QC)s, and 
seven B737-400(F)s. According to the ch-aviation fleets advanced module, the airline also operates six B737-700s 
and two B737-800s in passenger configurations. Sister carriers ASL Airlines Ireland (ABR, Dublin Int'l) and ASL 
Airlines Belgium (3V, Liège) operate two B737-800(BCF)s each, although the aircraft are not owned by ASL 
Aviation Holdings but rather dry-leased from GECAS.

during mid-day trading on Friday . The stock traded as high as GBX 17.10 ($0.22) and last traded at GBX 17.05 
($0.22), with a volume of 2459141 shares traded. The stock had previously closed at GBX 16.35 ($0.21). 
Separately, UBS Group  reiterated a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (RYA.L) in a research report on 
Monday, August 24th. 
The company has a current ratio of 0.87, a quick ratio of 0.80 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 112.18. The business's 
50 day moving average is GBX 13.82 and its 200 day moving average is GBX 12. The stock has a market 
capitalization of £191.86 million and a PE ratio of -19.17.

United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Germany, and Other European countries. It is also involved in the provision of various 
ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, 
food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation and hotel services, car hire, and travel insurance through its 
Website and mobile app.

Body
Ryanair logo Lansdowne Partners UK LLP reduced its stake in  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 19.2% 
during the 3rd quarter, according to its most recent Form 13F filing with the Securities & Exchange Commission. 
The institutional investor  owned 762,452 shares of the transportation company's stock after selling 180,974 shares 
during the quarter. Ryanair comprises approximately  2.5% of Lansdowne Partners UK LLP's portfolio, making the 
stock its 16th biggest holding. Lansdowne Partners UK LLP owned approximately 0.34% of Ryanair worth 
$62,338,000 as of its most recent filing with the Securities & Exchange Commission.  
Several other large investors also recently modified their holdings of RYAAY. FMR LLC increased its stake in  
Ryanair by 30.9% in the second quarter. FMR LLC now owns 5,276,515 shares of the transportation company's 
stock valued at $350,045,000 after purchasing an additional 1,246,442 shares during the last quarter.  JPMorgan 
Chase & Co. boosted its holdings in  Ryanair by 317.6% in the third quarter. JPMorgan Chase & Co. now owns 
851,985 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $68,602,000 after purchasing an additional 647,965 
shares during the last quarter.  BlackRock Inc. lifted its holdings in  Ryanair by 605.0% during the 3rd quarter. 
BlackRock Inc. now owns 419,697 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $34,314,000 after buying an 
additional 360,167 shares during the last quarter.  Sprucegrove Investment Management Ltd. lifted its holdings in  
Ryanair by 22.7% during the 2nd quarter. Sprucegrove Investment Management Ltd. now owns 1,880,474 shares 
of the transportation company's stock worth $124,751,000 after buying an additional 348,100 shares during the last 
quarter.  Finally, Massachusetts Financial Services Co. MA lifted its holdings in  Ryanair by 3.7% during the 3rd 
quarter. Massachusetts Financial Services Co. MA now owns 8,822,089 shares of the transportation company's 
stock worth $721,295,000 after buying an additional 316,925 shares during the last quarter. Institutional investors 
and hedge funds own  44.15% of the company's stock.  
A number of research analysts have commented on the company. Peel Hunt initiated coverage on Ryanair in a 
report on Tuesday, September 22nd. They set a "sell" rating on the stock. Credit Suisse Group  restated an 
"outperform" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Tuesday, November 10th. Liberum Capital cut 
Ryanair from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a research report on Monday, September 14th. Raymond James 
lifted their price target on Ryanair from $90.00 to $100.00 and gave the company an "outperform" rating in a 
research report on Wednesday, October 7th. Finally, Morgan Stanley  reiterated an "overweight" rating on shares of 
Ryanair in a research report on Tuesday, November 3rd. Two research analysts have rated the stock with a sell 
rating, six have given a hold rating and twelve have given a buy rating to the company. The company currently has 
a consensus rating of "Buy" and an average target price of $84.00.

Shares of RYAAY  traded up $7.01 during trading hours on Friday, hitting $116.60. 21,874 shares of the company 
were exchanged, compared to its average volume of 685,247. The company has a market capitalization of $26.24 
billion, a PE ratio of 103.60 and a beta of 1.40. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.57, a current ratio of 
0.67 and a quick ratio of 0.67. The firm has a fifty day simple moving average of $94.59 and a 200-day simple 
moving average of $80.55. Ryanair Holdings plc has a one year low of $44.44 and a one year high of $111.53.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last released its quarterly earnings data on Monday, November 2nd. The transportation 
company reported ($0.12) earnings per share for the quarter, topping the consensus estimate of ($0.26) by $0.14. 
The business had revenue of $1.23 billion during the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $1.17 billion. 
Ryanair had a return on equity of 10.45% and a net margin of 3.61%.  Sell-side analysts expect that  Ryanair 
Holdings plc will post -5.16 EPS for the current year.

day moving average price is $95.06 and its two-hundred day moving average price is $80.85. The company has a 
quick ratio of 0.67, a current ratio of 0.67 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.57.

United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Germany, and Other European countries. It is also involved in the provision of various 
ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, 
food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation and hotel services, car hire, and travel insurance through its 
Website and mobile app. 
Featured Article: Cash Flow 
Load-Date: December 4, 2020
End of Document
Ryanair orders additional 75 Boeing 737 Max aircraft
Ryanair orders additional 75 Boeing 737 Max aircraft
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
December 4, 2020 Friday 4:08 AM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 255 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair on Thursday signed a deal with Boeing for 75 of the manufacturer's MAX-8200 aircraft, 
increasing a previous order for the aircraft from 135 to 210.
The Irish airline said the deal was worth a total of 22 billion dollars.
"Now that the Boeing MAX aircraft has been certified by the FAA to return to service, Ryanair expects to take the 
first deliveries of these new fuel efficient and environmentally friendly aircraft from early 2021," the budget airline 
said.
The order is set to be delivered over a 4-year period ending in December 2024.
The EU's Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) last week announced Boeing's troubled 737 MAX will be allowed to take 
to the skies over Europe again from mid-January.
The decision follows the green light given to the aircraft by the US Federal Aviation Administration (FASA).
EASA is leaving open a window of four weeks for public comment on its decision, with a final ruling expected from 
the middle of January next year.
The decision follows numerous hardware and software changes and the retraining of pilots on the 737 MAX.
The aircraft was grounded in March 2019 following the death of 346 people in two accidents, one in Indonesia in 
October 2018 and another in Ethiopia in March 2019.
The main cause of the accidents was considered to be faulty control software that directed the jets towards the 
ground. Pilots were unable to overpower the automatic settings.
Ryanair orders additional 75 Boeing 737 Max aircraft
During the relicensing procedure, EASA acted in concert with the FAA and Boeing, but took its own independent 
decision.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Helen Corbett, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: December 3, 2020
End of Document

Boeing Shares Surge On Big 737 MAX Order, Global Stocks Mixed
Boeing Shares Surge On Big 737 MAX Order, Global Stocks Mixed
Newstex Blogs 
International Business Times Australia
December 4, 2020 Friday 12:05 AM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 625 words
Body
Dec 03, 2020( International Business Times Australia: http://www.ibtimes.com.au/ Delivered by Newstex)  Boeing 
shares surged Thursday after Ryanair confirmed a major order of Boeing 737 MAX jets while global stocks treaded 
water on mixed economic data. The deal for 75 planes by the Irish low-cost carrier was the first major order for the 
737 MAX since the aircraft was grounded for 20 months following two fatal crashes. The news, along with a 
successful test flight by American Airlines, help send shares in Boeing higher as the aircraft moves closer to 
returning to the skies after winning approval by US regulators last month. 
Shares in Boeing jumped 6.0 percent, helping to lift the Dow on a mixed day for US equities.  While the tech-rich 
Nasdaq edged to a fresh record, the broad-based S&#38;P 500 finished lower. European equities were also mixed, 
with London advancing and Paris and Frankfurt both pulling back. Data provider IHS Markit said its closely-watched 
composite eurozone purchasing managers' index (PMI) fell to 45.3 points in November from 50 in October, 
according to final estimates.Investors digested data showing slower growth in the US services sector in November 
and better-than-expected new unemployment claims ahead of Friday's closely-watched Labor Department jobs 
report. Markets have also monitored ongoing stimulus talks on Capitol Hill that have lifted hopes of a new spending 
package before the end of the year. "In general, the market is acting rationally in looking ahead to the other side of 
this," Art Hogan, chief market strategist at National Securities, said of the market's strength. But Hogan cautioned 
that stocks could be pressured later this month if rising US coronavirus cases stress hospital capacity, resulting in 
further business shutdowns. "The narrative about how the market is feeling optimistic about 2021 recovery 
prospects because of the arrival of Covid vaccines is growing a bit tired, yet market participants have been given a 
stimulant with the increased buzz on Capitol Hill about the need to get another stimulus package done soon," said 
market analyst Patrick J. O'Hare at Briefing.com. Elsewhere, oil prices advanced as members of the OPEC group 
of oil producers struck a deal to increase production over coming months, but by less than anticipated in their 
previous accord. Starting in January 2021, producers will pump 500,000 more barrels per day. The previous 
agreement entailed a cut of 7.7 million barrels per day (bpd) and had been scheduled to be eased to 5.8 million bpd 
on January 1. Meanwhile the pound surged to its highest level in a year, briefly rising above $1.35, after a 
government official expressed confidence on reaching a post-Brexit trade deal with the EU. Nancy Pelosi has 
welcomed a bipartisan stimulus proposal that investors hope can break a months-long deadlock with Republicans 
AFP / Nicholas Kamm  New York - Dow: UP 0.3 percent at 29,969.52 (close) New York - S&#38;P 500: DOWN 0.1 
percent at 3,666.72 (close) New York - Nasdaq: UP 0.2 percent at 12,377.18 (close) London - FTSE 100: UP 0.4 
percent at 6,490.27 (close) Frankfurt - DAX 30: DOWN 0.5 percent at 13,252.86 (close) Paris - CAC 40: DOWN 0.2 
percent at 5,574.36 (close) EURO STOXX 50: DOWN 0.1 percent at 3,517.10 (close) Tokyo - Nikkei 225: FLAT at 
Boeing Shares Surge On Big 737 MAX Order, Global Stocks Mixed
26,809.37 (close) Hong Kong - Hang Seng: UP 0.7 percent at 26,728.50 (close) Shanghai - Composite: DOWN 0.2 
percent at 3,442.14 (close) Euro/dollar: UP at $1.2147 from $1.2115 at 2200 GMT  Pound/dollar: UP at $1.3453 
from $1.3365 Dollar/yen: DOWN at 103.84 yen from 104.42 yen Euro/pound: DOWN at 90.28 pence from 90.65 
pence West Texas Intermediate: UP 0.8 percent at $45.64 per barrel Brent North Sea crude: UP 1.0 percent at 
$48.71 per barrel

Boeing clinches first Max jet order since fatal crashes 20 months ago ? Ryanair buys 75 planes ? Big discounts 
on $8bn list price likely ? US group's shares ris....
Boeing clinches first Max jet order since fatal crashes 20 months ago; ? 
Ryanair buys 75 planes ? Big discounts on $8bn list price likely ? US 
group's shares rise
Financial Times (London, England)
December 4, 2020 Friday
Edition 1, Asian Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1
Length: 484 words
Byline: PEGGY HOLLINGER; PHILIP GEORGIADIS ; CLAIRE BUSHEY
Body
Boeing has clinched its first firm order for the troubled 737 Max since it was grounded 20 months ago, with a 
multibillion-dollar deal for 75 aircraft from Ryanair marking the beginning of efforts to rehabilitate both the plane and 
the US aerospace maker's reputation.
After two fatal crashes within five months left 346 people dead, investigations revealed Boeing had concealed 
design flaws from pilots and regulators in a race to get the aircraft certified. The faulty anti-stall system, deemed a 
critical factor in the accidents, has been redesigned and pilots will go through more extensive training programmes.
The Federal Aviation Administration last month declared the jet safe to fly and other regulators are expected to 
follow suit in the coming weeks.
Michael O'Leary, chief executive of Ryanair, which was already one of Boeing's biggest Max customers, said that 
he was "confident that our customers will love these new aircraft".
At list prices, the order is worth close to $8bn, but analysts expect the Ryanair boss to have negotiated a steep 
discount. Normally, aircraft are sold at discounts of about 50 per cent to catalogue prices but the reduction is likely 
to have been even greater in the current climate.
Boeing clinches first Max jet order since fatal crashes 20 months ago ? Ryanair buys 75 planes ? Big discounts 
on $8bn list price likely ? US group's shares ris....
Mr O'Leary told the Financial Times that there had been a "modest" improvement in the pricing, adding: "It's not 
huge. But every modest reduction you can get when placing an order for up to $22bn, a small discount is a lot of 
money."
But Scott Hamilton of consultancy Leeham said he thought Mr O'Leary had probably got "a really screaming good 
deal" rather than simply a modest one.
The price could have been mitigated by relief on downpayments, on the cost of EU tariffs imposed on Boeing 
aircraft in the battle over subsidies, and "lots of flexibility on delivery slots", said Rob Stallard, analyst at Vertical 
Research.
Boeing chief executive Dave Calhoun said that he had "always had faith the order books would begin to fill" once 
regulators approved the aircraft as safe to fly and the industry recovered.
He also said Boeing's expectations of how long it would take the industry to bounce back from the pandemic had 
shifted following news of a coronavirus vaccine. The timeline to recovery was "a little more aggressive" than its 
earlier three to five-year forecast.
Ryanair's decision to commit to fleet expansion during one of the industry's deepest downturns also signals its 
determination to cement a cost advantage over emerging rivals such as Wizz Air.
Fleet data specialist Cirium noted that more than 1,000 Max orders had been cancelled or judged by Boeing to be 
at risk of cancellation this year alone.
For Boeing, the hope is that the order will spark confidence in the Max, which even before the crisis was lagging 
behind rival Airbus's A320 family in net orders. Investors appeared to agree yesterday, sending Boeing's share 
price 7.7 per cent higher by midday in New York.
Graphic
 
More than 1,000 orders for the US aerospace group's troubled Max 737 jet had been cancelled this year
Load-Date: December 3, 2020
End of Document

$8bn list price likely US group's shares rise
Boeing clinches first Max jet order since fatal crashes 20 months ago; 
Ryanair buys 75 planes Big discounts on $8bn list price likely US group's 
shares rise

Norwegian launches plan to downsize fleet and raise investor cash Airlines
Norwegian launches plan to downsize fleet and raise investor cash; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
December 4, 2020 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 12
Length: 463 words
Byline: PHILIP GEORGIADIS
Body
Norwegian Air Shuttle launched an emergency rescue plan yesterday to save the struggling low-cost airline, 
unveiling proposals to downsize its fleet and raise new money from investors.
It follows the filing for protection from creditors last month in Ireland under that country's equivalent of Chapter 11 
as it became aviation's largest casualty of the pandemic.
Norwegian's fate was sealed when the government refused to offer a second bailout, triggering the latest 
proceedings.
The company used Ireland to seek creditor protection as its subsidiaries there hold most of its aircraft.
The company's shares have declined 99 per cent in the past year, wiping out shareholders, as the stock was briefly 
suspended.
Norwegian's board proposed "reconstructing" the airline's balance sheet by reducing the size of its fleet, launching 
a new debt-for-equity swap and a rights issue of up to NKr4bn ($453m) in the form of new stock or hybrid 
instruments.
The debt-for-equity swap, which would be its second of the year, would include aircraft financing liabilities, supplier 
liabilities and bond obligations.
Norwegian launches plan to downsize fleet and raise investor cash Airlines
As part of the proposals, Norwegian said it could also only pay aircraft lessors when it used their planes to help it 
conserve cash, a so-called "power by the hour" deal.
The company gave no details as to the possible scale of the debt-for-equity swap, how many planes it could end up 
flying under the plan or how many jobs are at risk.
The proposals will be put forward at an extraordinary meeting on December 17.
The board said the plan would aim to "right-size" Norwegian's operations at a "level of proven profitability" and 
could attract new investors, including "potentially" new support from the state.
"Even in examinership, Norwegian has lost none of its ambition," analysts at Davy Research said. "The quantum of 
assistance it is looking for is material and, in particular, the request for additional debt-to-equity conversion will test 
creditors' patience."
Ministers in Oslo last month said they did not think it was a "sound use" of taxpayers' money to prop up the airline. 
The carrier went into the crisis as one of Europe's weakest due to a high level of debt built up through an 
aggressive expansion plan, including low-cost long-haul flights. It is operating only a skeleton service in its home 
market, using just six or seven of its planes following a 91 per cent fall in passenger numbers this year.
Founded in 1992 by former fighter pilot Bjorn Kjos, Norwegian grew over the past two decades to become a rival of 
Ryanair, easyJet and British Airways as it expanded from its Nordic base into low-cost travel in Europe and then 
with flights serving the US and Asia regions as well.
The carrier is operating a skeleton service after a 91% fall in passenger numbers this year
Load-Date: December 3, 2020
End of Document
Norwegian launches plan to downsize fleet and raise investor cash Airlines
Norwegian launches plan to downsize fleet and raise investor cash; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
December 4, 2020 Friday
Edition 1, European Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 8
Length: 464 words
Byline: PHILIP GEORGIADIS
Body
Norwegian Air Shuttle launched an emergency rescue plan yesterday to save the struggling low-cost airline, 
unveiling proposals to downsize its fleet and raise new money from investors.
It follows the filing for protection from creditors last month in Ireland under that country's equivalent of Chapter 11 
as it became aviation's largest casualty of the pandemic.
Norwegian's fate was sealed when the government refused to offer a second bailout, triggering the latest 
proceedings.
The company used Ireland to seek creditor protection as its subsidiaries there hold most of its aircraft.
The company's shares have declined 99 per cent in the past year, wiping out shareholders, as the stock was briefly 
suspended.
Norwegian's board proposed "reconstructing" the airline's balance sheet by reducing the size of its fleet, launching 
a new debt-for-equity swap and a rights issue of up to NKr4bn ($453m) in the form of new stock or hybrid 
instruments.
The debt-for-equity swap, which would be its second of the year, would include aircraft financing liabilities, supplier 
liabilities and bond obligations.
Norwegian launches plan to downsize fleet and raise investor cash Airlines
As part of the proposals, Norwegian said it could also only pay aircraft lessors when it used their planes to help it 
conserve cash, a so-called "power by the hour" deal.
The company gave no details as to the possible scale of the debt-for-equity swap, how many planes it could end up 
flying under the plan or how many jobs are at risk.
The proposals will be put forward at an extraordinary meeting on December 17.
The board said the plan would aim to "right-size" Norwegian's operations at a "level of proven profitability" and 
could attract new investors, including "potentially" new support from the state.
"Even in examinership, Norwegian has lost none of its ambition," analysts at Davy Research said. "The quantum of 
assistance it is looking for is material and, in particular, the request for additional debt-to-equity conversion will test 
creditors' patience."
Ministers in Oslo last month said they did not think it was a "sound use" of taxpayers' money to prop up the airline. 
The carrier went into the crisis as one of Europe's weakest due to a high level of debt built up through an 
aggressive expansion plan, including low-cost long-haul flights. It is operating only a skeleton service in its home 
market, using just six or seven of its planes following a 91 per cent fall in passenger numbers this year.
Founded in 1992 by former fighter pilot Bjorn Kjos, Norwegian grew over the past two decades to become a rival of 
Ryanair, easyJet and British Airways as it expanded from its Nordic base into low-cost travel in Europe and then 
with flights serving the US and Asia regions as well.
The carrier is operating a skeleton service after a decline of 91% this year in passenger numbers
Load-Date: December 3, 2020
End of Document

Boeing takes order for more 737 MAX jets after return to service
Boeing takes order for more 737 MAX jets after return to service
Newstex Blogs 
ValueWalk
December 4, 2020 Friday 3:06 PM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 597 words
Byline: Michelle Jones
Body
Dec 04, 2020( ValueWalk: http://www.valuewalk.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Boeing stock is rallying after the 
company said it sold 75 more 737 MAX jets to Ryanair. The aircraft is set to return to regular service by the end of 
the year, finally bringing an end to a long-running struggle for Boeing[1].  Get The Full Series in PDF Get the entire 
10-part series on Charlie Munger in PDF. Save it to your desktop, read it on your tablet, or email to your colleagues. 
Q3 2020 hedge fund letters, conferences and more[2] The timing couldn't be better because the company is also 
dealing with the impacts[3] of the COVID-19 pandemic, which has led many airlines to cancel orders for planes.This 
is the second part of a short series on Michael J. Mauboussin's research document reflecting on 30 years of Wall 
Street analysis published in 2016. Q3 2020 hedge fund letters, conferences and more The document outlined 
Mauboussin's observations of successful investors throughout his three decades on the Street. This article starts at 
point six. Read More[4]   Boeing sells 737 MAX aircraft to RyanairIn November, the Federal Aviation Administration 
cleared the Boeing 737 MAX aircraft to fly again, the company said on Thursday. Wasting no time, Boeing has 
already taken an order for the airplanes from European budget airline Ryanair, according to Fox Business[5]. 
Ryanair placed a "firm order" for 75 more of the airplanes, which will bring the number of 737 MAX jets it operates 
to 210. The airline initially ordered 100 of the jets with 100 options in 2014 and then ordered 10 more in 2017 and 
an additional 25 the next year. Ryanair said its latest order for 75 Boeing 737 MAX aircraft is worth more than $22 
billion. Boeing and Ryanair reached an agreement for revised dates of delivery. Boeing will also compensate the 
airline for costs it incurred due to delays in delivery from the previous orders because the aircraft[6] were grounded 
for over a year. Ryanair CEO Michael O'Leary said they expect to receive the first 50 Boeing 737 MAX jets next 
year.Jets returned to serviceBoeing President and CEO Dave Calhoun said in a statement that the airplane maker 
"remains focused on safely returning the full 737 fleet to service and on delivering the backlog of airplanes to 
Ryanair and our other customers in the new year." The FAA issued the first airworthiness certificate to one of the 
Boeing 737 MAX jets on Monday, according to Fox News[7]. Boeing plans to deliver about half of the aircraft it has 
in storage by the end of next year. Ryanair ordered the 737 8-200, which has more capacity than the 737-8. Boeing 
has said the airplane allows for more seats and offers better fuel efficiency and environmental performance. 
Ryanair described the airplane as a "gamechanger." The airline configured its 737 jets with 197 seats and plans to 
use them for low-fare service to new European markets as the COVID-19 vaccine becomes available, hopefully 
returning the travel industry to "normal." [ 1]: https://www.valuewalk.com/2020/09/boeing-co-737-max-design-flaws/

Ryanair Orders 75 Additional Boeing 737 MAX Jets
Ryanair Orders 75 Additional Boeing 737 MAX Jets
Newstex Blogs 
Financial Buzz
December 4, 2020 Friday 4:11 PM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 343 words
Byline: Andy Liao
Body
Dec 04, 2020( Financial Buzz: http://www.financialbuzz.com Delivered by Newstex)  Boeing Company (NYSE: BA) 
and Ryanair report[1] that Europe's largest airline will place an order for 75 additional 737 max airplanes, bringing 
the total order book to 210 jets. Ryanair has selected the 737 8-200, citing its increased seats and improved fuel 
efficiency and environmental performance. 
'Ryanair's board and people are confident that our customers will love these new aircraft. Passengers will enjoy the 
new interiors, more generous leg room, lower fuel consumption and quieter noise performance. And, most of all, our 
customers will love the lower fares, which these aircraft will enable Ryanair to offer starting in 2021 and for the next 
decade, as Ryanair leads the recovery ofEurope'saviation and tourism industries,' said Ryanair Group CEOMichael 
O'Leary. 'As soon as the COVID-19 virus recedes - and it likely will in 2021 with the rollout of multiple effective 
vaccines - Ryanair and our partner airports acrossEuropewill - with these environmentally efficient aircraft - rapidly 
restore flights and schedules, recover lost traffic and help the nations ofEuroperecover their tourism industries, and 
get young people back to work across the cities, beaches and ski resorts of the European Union,' O'Leary said. 
'Ryanair will continue to play a leading role in our industry whenEuroperecovers from the COVID-19 pandemic and 
air traffic returns to growth across the continent. We are gratified that Ryanair is once again placing its confidence in 
the Boeing 737 family and building their future fleet with this enlarged firm order,' saidDave Calhoun, president and 
CEO of The Boeing Company. 'Boeing remains focused on safely returning the full 737 fleet to service and on 
delivering the backlog of airplanes to Ryanair and our other customers. We firmly believe in this airplane, and we 
will 
continue 
the 
work 
to 
re-earn 
the 
trust 
of 
all 
of 
our 
customers,' 
Calhoun 
said.

Wall Street
Wall Street
Financial Times (London, England)
December 4, 2020 Friday
Edition 1, USA Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS; Pg. 13
Length: 197 words
Body
Boeing climbed after revealing that low-cost airline Ryanair was ordering 75 737 Max jets - the aircraft that was 
grounded after two fatal accidents left 346 people dead.
The Federal Aviation Administration last month declared the jet safe to fly and other regulators were expected to do 
the same in coming weeks.
Shares in the Chicago-based multinational are down more than a quarter this year following its efforts to resume 
production of the Max and the downturn in airline passenger numbers.
Data platform Splunk plummeted after third-quarter results showed a net loss per share of $0.07, missing 
expectations.
Almost every key quarterly growth metric was missed, said UBS analyst Karl Keirstead, commenting on Splunk's 
earnings.
The California group "pinned the blame on a late-October deterioration in close rates, as enterprises hesitated on 
signing large deals given greater cost scrutiny", said Mr Keirstead. "This is consistent with our own field checks."
Forecast-beating results sent CrowdStrike higher.
For the third quarter, the cyber security company reported total revenues of $232.5m, an 86 per cent increase 
compared with $125.1m in the same period last year. Ray Douglas
Wall Street
Load-Date: December 3, 2020
End of Document

ETFs to Win on Boeing Shares Gain: Prospects Look Bright
ETFs to Win on Boeing Shares Gain: Prospects Look Bright
Newstex Blogs 
Zacks Investment Research
December 4, 2020 Friday 1:31 PM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 912 words
Byline: Sanghamitra Saha
Body
Dec 04, 2020( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Shares of Boeing 
Company BA[1] gained about 6% on Dec 3as the low-cost Irish airlineRyanairordered 75 extra Boeing 737 Max 
jets[2] with a value of $9 billion. The news acted as a fresh lifeline to the struggling U.S. planemaker after regulators 
lifted a 20-month safety ban recently.On Nov 18, Boeing won approval from the U.S. Federal Aviation 
Administration (FAA) to start re-operation of its 737 MAX jet after two fatal crashes (in Indonesia and Ethiopia) that 
caused two years of regulatory scrutiny and corporate chaos.The FAA elaborated software upgrades and training 
changes Boeing must put into effect for the jet to recommence commercial flights after a 20-month grounding[3], the 
longest in commercial aviation history, per Economic Times. The Economic Times article indicated that the single-
aisle jets like the MAX and rival Airbus A320neo are pillars of the global fleet and huge contributors to the global 
industry profit.Ryanairis one of Boeing's most important buyers. Boeing already has an order of 135 of the 197-seat 
Max 200 from Ryanair. 
Ryanair's first jet on order will likely be delivered early next year and the final one by the end of 2024.No wonder, 
the news offered Boeing substantial gains. The airline added about 0.7% after hours on Dec 3. 'This is the 
beginning of the fulfillment of a more robust order book,' Boeing Chief Executive David Calhoun said at a signing 
event in Washington DC, as quoted on CNBC.To add to this, American Airlines AAL[4] is also 'flying its 
employees[5], including top executives, and reporters on its Boeing 737 Max planes this week' in order to boost 
confidence among the passengers. 'Boeing is also negotiating with airlines includingSouthwestandDeltaandAlaska 
Airlines, which last month agreed to lease 13 Boeing Max jets, industry sources have said,' as quoted on 
CNBC.Against this backdrop, though we believe that the Boeing stock does not offer an aggressive buying 
opportunity even after the FAA approval and Ryanair's order, the hopes of improvement in Boeing business can be 
played via basket approach. The basket approach or the ETF route minimizes the stock-specific risks. Below we 
highlight a few such ETF options. Boeing-Heavy ETFs in Focus iShares U.S. Aerospace &#38; Defense ETF ITA[6] 
- Boeing has about 9.84% weight; up 1.67% on Dec 3Invesco Aerospace &#38; Defense ETF PPA[7] - Boeing has 
about 8.86% weight; up 1.29% on Dec 3SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average ETF DIA[8] - Boeing has about 4.44% 
weight; up 0.29% on Dec 3 Want key ETF info delivered straight to your inbox? Zacks' free Fund Newsletter will 
brief you on top news and analysis, as well as top-performing ETFs, each week.Get it free  > >[9]Want the latest 
recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days.

Boeing takes order for more 737 MAX jets after return to service
Boeing takes order for more 737 MAX jets after return to service
Newstex Blogs 
Phil's Stock World
December 4, 2020 Friday 5:41 PM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 570 words
Byline: ValueWalk
Body
Dec 04, 2020( Phil's Stock World: http://www.philstockworld.com Delivered by Newstex)  By Michelle Jones. 
Originally published at ValueWalk[1].Boeing stock is rallying after the company said it sold 75 more 737 MAX jets to 
Ryanair. The aircraft is set to return to regular service by the end of the year, finally bringing an end to a long-
running struggle for Boeing[2].   Q3 2020 hedge fund letters, conferences and more[3] The timing couldn't be better 
because the company is also dealing with the impacts[4] of the COVID-19 pandemic, which has led many airlines to 
cancel orders for planes.Boeing sells 737 MAX aircraft to RyanairIn November, the Federal Aviation Administration 
cleared the Boeing 737 MAX aircraft to fly again, the company said on Thursday. 
Wasting no time, Boeing has already taken an order for the airplanes from European budget airline Ryanair, 
according to Fox Business[5]. Ryanair placed a 'firm order' for 75 more of the airplanes, which will bring the number 
of 737 MAX jets it operates to 210. The airline initially ordered 100 of the jets with 100 options in 2014 and then 
ordered 10 more in 2017 and an additional 25 the next year. Ryanair said its latest order for 75 Boeing 737 MAX 
aircraft is worth more than $22 billion. Boeing and Ryanair reached an agreement for revised dates of delivery. 
Boeing will also compensate the airline for costs it incurred due to delays in delivery from the previous orders 
because the aircraft[6] were grounded for over a year. Ryanair CEO Michael O'Leary said they expect to receive 
the first 50 Boeing 737 MAX jets next year.Jets returned to serviceBoeing President and CEO Dave Calhoun said in 
a statement that the airplane maker 'remains focused on safely returning the full 737 fleet to service and on 
delivering the backlog of airplanes to Ryanair and our other customers in the new year.' The FAA issued the first 
airworthiness certificate to one of the Boeing 737 MAX jets on Monday, according to Fox News[7]. Boeing plans to 
deliver about half of the aircraft it has in storage by the end of next year. Ryanair ordered the 737 8-200, which has 
more capacity than the 737-8. Boeing has said the airplane allows for more seats and offers better fuel efficiency 
and environmental performance. Ryanair described the airplane as a 'gamechanger.' The airline configured its 737 
jets with 197 seats and plans to use them for low-fare service to new European markets as the COVID-19 vaccine 
becomes available, hopefully returning the travel industry to 'normal.' https://mixi.media/ The post Boeing takes 
order for more 737 MAX jets after return to service[8] appeared first on ValueWalk[9]. Sign up for ValueWalk's free 
newsletter 
here[10].

Boeing gets a boost from Ryanair order for 75 more Max jets
Boeing gets a boost from Ryanair order for 75 more Max jets
Associated Press Financial Wire
December 3, 2020 Thursday 9:53 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 479 words
Byline: DAVID KOENIG, AP Airlines Writer
Body
Irish budget airline Ryanair said Thursday it is ordering 75 more Boeing 737 Max jets, a boost for Boeing just before 
its most important plane returns to flying after two deadly crashes.
The order would be worth more than $9 billion at list prices, although airlines routinely receive deep discounts. 
Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.
Boeing shares rose 6% to $237.20, their highest closing price in nearly nine months.
The announcement was a huge lift for Chicago-based Boeing, which has suffered canceled orders for the plane 
since it was grounded nearly 21 months ago and while demand for new jets plummeted because of the coronavirus 
pandemic.
So far this year, customers have canceled orders for 448 Max jets and Boeing has raised doubt about another 782 
orders because of the airlines’ pandemic-weakened financial health. Before Ryanair’s order, the company had 
reported only five Max orders in 2020.
Boeing CEO David Calhoun said he is confident that the Ryanair move is the beginning of the company's bid to 
rebuild its Max order book.
Airlines usually get deep discounts off list prices for planes. Calhoun dismissed the idea that Boeing may be under 
more pressure to cut prices because of a pandemic that is causing massive losses at its airline customers and the 
Max's own troubled past. The company is trying to resell planes covered by previous deals that were later canceled.
“We don't feel a need to discount our way into the marketplace,” he said.
The new deal would push Ryanair’s total orders for the Max to 210 planes. CEO Michael O’Leary said that with the 
additional 75 planes, Max jets will make up one-third of Ryanair’s fleet in five years, up from 6% now.
O’Leary said the planes offer lower fuel consumption and quieter flying than other aircraft. He expressed confidence 
that travel will recover next year as virus vaccines become widely available and that customers will get back on the 
Max.
Boeing gets a boost from Ryanair order for 75 more Max jets
“The one issue that's going to come up here today is safety, so let's get it out front,” O'Leary said on a call with 
reporters. “This is the most scrutinized, most audited aircraft in history. It's also going to be one of the safest.”
Max jets were grounded worldwide in March 2019 after crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia just five months apart 
killed a total of 346 people. Last month the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration and regulators in Europe cleared 
the way for the plane's return by prescribing new flight-control software and other changes.
Brazil's Gol airline plans to operate flights with paying passengers starting next week. American Airlines plans the 
first U.S. flight for Dec. 29 from Miami to New York.
With its previously best-selling plane grounded, Boeing has lost $3.5 billion so far this year and announced deep 
jobs cuts to reduce costs. Boeing expects the pandemic to cast a pall over demand for airline jets for several years.
Load-Date: December 3, 2020
End of Document
Midday Report: US Stocks Rise, Dollar Slumps to Two-Year Low Amid Drop in Jobless Claims, Prospect of 
Fiscal Relief
Midday Report: US Stocks Rise, Dollar Slumps to Two-Year Low Amid Drop 
in Jobless Claims, Prospect of Fiscal Relief
MT Newswires Live Briefs
December 3, 2020 Thursday 1:05 PM EST
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 513 words
Body
 US stocks rose as initial jobless claims fell more than expected and the dollar depreciated to its lowest level in 
more than two years amid expectations of a $908 billion bipartisan fiscal stimulus package.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose by 175.40 points, or 0.6%, to 30,057.56, with the S&P 500 higher by 0.2% 
to 3,674.53 and the Nasdaq Composite Index was up by 0.5% to 12,405.34. Industrials and real-estate were among 
the biggest gainers while utilities led the decliners after midday on Thursday.
The US 10-year yield fell by 2.3 basis points to 0.92%.
US initial jobless claims for the Nov. 28 week fell to 712,000, lagging the consensus forecast compiled by 
Bloomberg for 775,000. The four-week moving average slid to 739,500, resuming the string of declines seen over 
the last few months. Continuing claims fell to 5.52 million in the Nov. 21 week, maintaining a downward trend but 
still sharply elevated.
"Prior to this week, claims increased in two consecutive weeks for the first time since July," Analysts Thomas 
Simons and Aneta Markowska said in a report. "It had appeared that the labor market recovery had hit an inflection 
point, but today's data is more encouraging."
The leadership of the Democrats is supporting a bipartisan compromise for the stimulus package, according to a 
report from Commerzbank. The dollar depreciated by 0.5% against the Japanese yen to 103.83.
"Additional fiscal stimulus ahead of the new President Joe Biden assuming office would lower the current downside 
risks for the economy and thus principally fuel inflation expectations, which will weaken the dollar in view of the 
Fed's long-term expansionary monetary policy targets," Commerzbank Analyst Esther Reichelt said.
Midday Report: US Stocks Rise, Dollar Slumps to Two-Year Low Amid Drop in Jobless Claims, Prospect of 
Fiscal Relief
West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures rose by 0.6% to $45.55, after trading lower earlier in the session, ahead 
of a decision from the Organization for the Petroleum Exporting Countries and non-OPEC producers led by Russia 
in relation to the extension of production cuts in the first quarter. Media reports speculated joint cuts will be eased 
by 500,000 per day instead of 2 million barrels per day to bring on board the United Arab Emirates, the main 
dissenter.
In company news, DocuSign (DOCU) rose 6.7% ahead of the expected release of quarterly results Thursday after 
the bell.  Boeing (BA) topped the Dow with shares jumping 7.9% intraday after Ryanair (RYAAY) placed a firm order 
for 75 additional 737 MAX airplanes, expanding its order book to 210 jets.
On the S&P 500, top performers included COVID-19 plays such as Carnival (CCL), Norwegian Cruise Line (NCLH), 
and American Airlines (AAL), with gains of at least 9% each intraday.
In the precious metals markets, gold was up 0.4% to $1,837.40 an ounce, with silver unchanged at $24.08.
Among energy ETFs, the United States Oil Fund rose 0.7% to $31.20 and the United States Natural Gas Fund was 
down 8.4% to $9.13. Among precious-metal funds, the Market Vectors Gold Miners ETF was down 1.2% to $35.49 
and SPDR Gold Shares were up 0.5% to $172.35. The iShares Silver Trust was little changed at $22.33.
Load-Date: December 3, 2020
End of Document
Close Update: Stocks End Mixed Despite Record-Breaking Gains as Pfizer 's Vaccine Facing Supply Chain 
Issues
Close Update: Stocks End Mixed Despite Record-Breaking Gains as Pfizer's 
Vaccine Facing Supply Chain Issues
MT Newswires Live Briefs
December 3, 2020 Thursday 4:46 PM EST
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 526 words
Body
 US stocks ended mixed despite record-breaking intraday gains from the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq as reports came 
in late in the day that Pfizer (PFE) is slashing half the COVID-19 vaccines it was targeting to ship this year due to 
supply chain issues. Last week's initial jobless claims were lower than expected amid expectations of a reported 
$908 billion bipartisan fiscal stimulus.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose by 0.3% to 29,969.52. The S&P 500 was near flat at 3,666.72 and the 
Nasdaq Composite was up by 0.2% to 12,377.18. Energy and real estate were among the biggest gainers while 
utilities and materials led the decliners on Thursday.
US initial jobless claims for the Nov. 28 week fell to 712,000, lagging the consensus forecast compiled by 
Bloomberg for 775,000. The four-week moving average slid to 739,500, resuming the string of declines seen over 
the last few months. Continuing claims fell to 5.52 million in the Nov. 21 week, maintaining a downward trend but 
still sharply elevated.
"Prior to this week, claims increased in two consecutive weeks for the first time since July," Analysts Thomas 
Simons and Aneta Markowska said in a report from Jefferies. "It had appeared that the labor market recovery had 
hit an inflection point, but today's data is more encouraging."
"That being said, claims data for the week of Thanksgiving is notoriously difficult to process due to issues with the 
seasonal adjustment process. The decline this week is encouraging, but also difficult to trust," they said.
Meanwhile, the leadership of the Democrats is supporting a bipartisan compromise for the stimulus package, 
according to a report from Commerzbank.
Close Update: Stocks End Mixed Despite Record-Breaking Gains as Pfizer 's Vaccine Facing Supply Chain 
Issues
"Additional fiscal stimulus ahead of the new President Joe Biden assuming office would lower the current downside 
risks for the economy and thus principally fuel inflation expectations, which will weaken the dollar in view of the 
Fed's long-term expansionary monetary policy targets," Commerzbank Analyst Esther Reichelt said.
West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures rose by 0.9% to $45.68, after the Organization for the Petroleum 
Exporting Countries and non-OPEC producers led by Russia decided to raise output by 500,000 per day, well 
below the 2 million barrels per day that was initially agreed upon.
In company news, DocuSign (DOCU) rose 6.7% ahead of the expected release of quarterly results Thursday after 
the bell.  Boeing (BA) topped the Dow with shares jumping 7.9% intraday after Ryanair (RYAAY) placed a firm order 
for 75 additional 737 MAX airplanes, expanding its order book to 210 jets.
On the S&P 500, top performers included COVID-19 plays such as Carnival (CCL), Norwegian Cruise Line (NCLH), 
and American Airlines (AAL), with gains of at least 9% each intraday.
In the precious metals markets, gold was up 0.4% to $1,837.40 an ounce, with silver unchanged at $24.08.
Among energy ETFs, the United States Oil Fund rose 0.7% to $31.20 and the United States Natural Gas Fund was 
down 8.4% to $9.13. Among precious-metal funds, the Market Vectors Gold Miners ETF was down 1.2% to $35.49 
and SPDR Gold Shares were up 0.5% to $172.35. The iShares Silver Trust was little changed at $22.33.

Vaccine Warning

Market Summary: Stocks surrendered most Thursday's gains and quickly lost altitude into the close as reports that 
Pfizer cut its vaccine rollout due to supply-chain obstacles and concerns about component quality triggered profit-
taking. The Dow and Nasdaq still closed with modest gains, though were off substantially from their late-afternoon

for a third consecutive day.

0.911% and the 30-yr yield fell 2.7bps to 1.658. Market participants are bracing for a 1.0% yield on the 10-yr should 
Friday's labor market report show a 475K or higher gain in November non-farm payrolls.

S&P 500, Dow Head Toward Third Straight Win as Jobless Claims Decrease, McConnell Sees Stimulus Deal 
'In Reach'
S&P 500, Dow Head Toward Third Straight Win as Jobless Claims Decrease, 
McConnell Sees Stimulus Deal 'In Reach'
MT Newswires Live Briefs PRO
December 3, 2020 Thursday 12:36 PM EST
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 442 words
Body
 Stocks gained ground Thursday, as investors kept the Standard & Poor's 500 Index at record highs following a 
decline in Americans filing for jobless claims and after the US Senate leader expressed optimism about crafting a 
new COVID-19 relief bill. 
The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones Industrial Average were on track for a third consecutive win while the Nasdaq 
Composite was erasing the small loss it logged on Wednesday.
Stocks largely extended gains after the Labor Department early Thursday said weekly filings for initial 
unemployment aid fell by 75,000 to 712,000, the largest decline since early October. An Econoday survey had 
projected filings of 780,000.
Claims in the previous two weeks had increased for the first time since July, suggesting "the labor market recovery 
had hit an inflection point, but today's data is more encouraging," said Jefferies economists Thomas Simons and 
Aneta Markowska in a note. "That being said, claims data for the week of Thanksgiving is notoriously difficult to 
process due to issues with the seasonal adjustment process," they cautioned.
The jobless figures also showed that more than 20 million Americans are still receiving unemployment benefits 
during the ongoing coronavirus health crisis. The US is currently mired in record-high figures for new infections, with 
daily tallies surpassing 200,000.
Senate Leader Mitch McConnell on the Senate floor Thursday reportedly said he thinks a deal is in sight for a new 
round of fiscal stimulus to address the pandemic. "Compromise is within reach. We know where we agree. We can 
do this," he said, according to a CNBC report.
On the Dow, 20 of its 30 components were higher. Boeing (BA) jumped nearly 8% with Irish carrier Ryanair 
(RYAAY) placing a firm order for 75 additional 737 Max airplanes.
S&P 500, Dow Head Toward Third Straight Win as Jobless Claims Decrease, McConnell Sees Stimulus Deal 
'In Reach'
Six of the 11 industry sectors on the S&P 500 rose. The energy group was up 1.4% but slightly pared the gain 
following reports that OPEC and its allies have agreed to begin modestly increasing oil output in 2021.
Among corporate movers, Express (EXPR) shares sank 19%, with the apparel retailer posting a wider-than-
expected adjusted loss of $1.17 per share for its fiscal third quarter. Also, AMC Entertainment (AMC) fell 58% after 
the movie theater chain operator filed a securities shelf registration to sell up to 200 million class A shares. Shares 
may be sold from time to time, it said.
CrowdStrike Holdings (CRWD) surged 14% as the cybersecurity technology company raised its 2021 financial 
guidance and unexpectedly swung to adjusted earnings in the third quarter.
In afternoon trading, the Dow rose 0.6%, the S&P 500 added on 0.2% and the Nasdaq Composite was up 0.5%.
Load-Date: December 3, 2020
End of Document
Wall Street Lifted As Boeing Shares Take Flight
Wall Street Lifted As Boeing Shares Take Flight
Newstex Blogs 
International Business Times News
December 3, 2020 Thursday 5:50 PM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 614 words
Body
Dec 03, 2020( International Business Times News: http://www.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex)  Wall Street's 
main stock indices pushed higher on Thursday after Ryanair confirmed a major order of Boeing 737 MAX jets.The 
deal for 75 of the planes by the Irish low-cost carrier was the first major order for the 737 MAX since the aircraft was 
grounded for 20 months following two fatal crashes.The news, along with a successful test flight by American 
Airlines, help send shares in Boeing higher as the aircraft moves closer to returning to the skies after winning 
approval by US regulators last month.Shares in Boeing surged 7.4 percent higher.In late morning trading, the Dow 
was 0.6 percent higher, with the S&#38;P 500 pushing further into record territory. Sentiment was also helped by 
movement towards a new stimulus package.Speaker Nancy Pelosi threw her support behind a $908-billion 
compromise virus relief package proposed by a bipartisan group of lawmakers on Tuesday. The proposal is 
however half what Democrats had previously been pushing for."The narrative about how the market is feeling 
optimistic about 2021 recovery prospects because of the arrival of Covid vaccines is growing a bit tired, yet market 
participants have been given a stimulant with the increased buzz on Capitol Hill about the need to get another 
stimulus package done soon," said market analyst Patrick J. O'Hare at Briefing.com.He added that the continued 
high number of new jobless claims along with more than 100,000 Covid-19 hospitalisations in the US were factors 
in the market viewing it as likely that a deal will be done relatively soon.The eurozone's equity markets slipped on 
survey data indicating the region's economy continued to be battered by coronavirus fallout.In eurozone trades 
Thursday, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index shed 0.5 percent and the Paris CAC 40 dropped 0.2 percent.Data provider IHS 
Markit said its closely-watched composite eurozone purchasing managers' index (PMI) fell to 45.3 points in 
November from 50 in October, according to final estimates.Britain's services PMI dropped to 47.6 from 51.4. A level 
below 50 points indicates contraction.Nevertheless, London's FTSE 100 managed a 0.4 percent gain thanks to a 
good performance by international mining stocks. 
Nancy Pelosi has welcomed a bipartisan stimulus proposal that investors hope can break a months-long deadlock 
with Republicans Photo: AFP / Nicholas Kamm Meanwhile the pound surged to its highest level in a year, briefly 
rising above $1.35, after a government official expressed confidence on reaching a post-Brexit trade deal with the 
EU."It's the kind of comment that has been heard before in the last couple of weeks, without anything materialising," 
said market analyst Connor Campbell at Spreadex. "Nevertheless, with the deadline looming, sterling will take what 
it can get."Oil prices drifted higher as a crucial OPEC gathering debated whether to extend the current level of 
output cuts.New York - Dow: UP 0.6 percent at 30,057.37London - FTSE 100: UP 0.4 percent at 6,490.27 points 
(close)Frankfurt - DAX 30: DOWN 0.5 percent at 13,252.86 (close)Paris - CAC 40: DOWN 0.2 percent at 5,574.36 
(close)EURO STOXX 50: DOWN less than 0.1 percent at 3,518.78Tokyo - Nikkei 225: FLAT at 26,809.37 
Wall Street Lifted As Boeing Shares Take Flight
(close)Hong Kong - Hang Seng: UP 0.7 percent at 26,728.50 (close)Shanghai - Composite: DOWN 0.2 percent at 
3,442.14 (close)Euro/dollar: UP at $1.2149 from $1.2115 at 2200 GMTPound/dollar: UP at $1.3493 from 
$1.3365Dollar/yen: DOWN at 103.82 yen from 104.42 yenEuro/pound: DOWN at 90.07 pence from 90.65 
penceWest Texas Intermediate: UP 0.2 percent at $45.38 per barrelBrent North Sea crude: UP 0.3 percent at 
$48.41

Boeing 737 MAX Completes First Public Flight Since Grounding
Boeing 737 MAX Completes First Public Flight Since Grounding
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
December 03, 2020
Copyright 2020 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business News; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 305 words
Body
The first post-grounding, non-test flight for Boeing's 737 MAX fleet of planes took place Wednesday, as the aircraft 
carried members of the media between Dallas and Tulsa, Oklahoma.
According to Reuters.com, American Airlines hosted the 45-minute flight for around 90 reporters, flight attendants 
and other employees, with the energy inside the plane described as "subdued."
While some passengers interacted during the journey using facial coverings and social distancing, the entire group 
cheered when the aircraft landed successfully. Wednesday's flight marked the first time anyone other than 
regulators and industry personnel flew on the MAX since the grounding.
Boeing's737 MAX fleet was grounded in March 2019 after two crashes in five months that killed a combined 346 
people. After a 20-month safety ban, the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) cleared the plane after approving 
design changes and new pilot training.
"The history of aviation is built around a chain of safety," American Airlines Captain Pete Gamble told Reuters 
before takeoff. "When the chain of safety breaks it's up to those of us in the industry to mend it and bring it back."
The first post-grounding MAX flight with paying customers will take off on December 29.
Despite the previous issues with the plane, United Airlines is expected to receive the first 737 MAX delivery since 
the grounding, while European low-cost carrier Ryanair was reportedly set to place an order for up to 75 additional 
MAX planes.

Boeing 737 MAX Completes First Public Flight Since Grounding
End of Document

Boeing 737 MAX Completes First Public Flight Since Grounding

December 03, 2020

Body
The first post-grounding, non-test flight for Boeing's 737 MAX fleet of planes took place Wednesday, as the aircraft 
carried members of the media between Dallas and Tulsa, Oklahoma.
According to Reuters.com, American Airlines hosted the 45-minute flight for around 90 reporters, flight attendants 
and other employees, with the energy inside the plane described as "subdued."

Boeing Shares Surge On Big 737 MAX Order, Global Stocks Mixed
Boeing Shares Surge On Big 737 MAX Order, Global Stocks Mixed
Newstex Blogs 
International Business Times News
December 3, 2020 Thursday 10:45 PM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 620 words
Body
Dec 03, 2020( International Business Times News: http://www.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex)  Boeing shares 
surged Thursday after Ryanair confirmed a major order of Boeing 737 MAX jets while global stocks treaded water 
on mixed economic data.The deal for 75 planes by the Irish low-cost carrier was the first major order for the 737 
MAX since the aircraft was grounded for 20 months following two fatal crashes.The news, along with a successful 
test flight by American Airlines, help send shares in Boeing higher as the aircraft moves closer to returning to the 
skies after winning approval by US regulators last month.Shares in Boeing jumped 6.0 percent, helping to lift the 
Dow on a mixed day for US equities.While the tech-rich Nasdaq edged to a fresh record, the broad-based S&#38;P 
500 finished lower.European equities were also mixed, with London advancing and Paris and Frankfurt both pulling 
back.Data provider IHS Markit said its closely-watched composite eurozone purchasing managers' index (PMI) fell 
to 45.3 points in November from 50 in October, according to final estimates. Investors digested data showing slower 
growth in the US services sector in November and better-than-expected new unemployment claims ahead of 
Friday's closely-watched Labor Department jobs report.Markets have also monitored ongoing stimulus talks on 
Capitol Hill that have lifted hopes of a new spending package before the end of the year."In general, the market is 
acting rationally in looking ahead to the other side of this," Art Hogan, chief market strategist at National Securities, 
said of the market's strength.But Hogan cautioned that stocks could be pressured later this month if rising US 
coronavirus cases stress hospital capacity, resulting in further business shutdowns."The narrative about how the 
market is feeling optimistic about 2021 recovery prospects because of the arrival of Covid vaccines is growing a bit 
tired, yet market participants have been given a stimulant with the increased buzz on Capitol Hill about the need to 
get another stimulus package done soon," said market analyst Patrick J. O'Hare at Briefing.com.Elsewhere, oil 
prices advanced as members of the OPEC group of oil producers struck a deal to increase production over coming 
months, but by less than anticipated in their previous accord.Starting in January 2021, producers will pump 500,000 
more barrels per day. 
The previous agreement entailed a cut of 7.7 million barrels per day (bpd) and had been scheduled to be eased to 
5.8 million bpd on January 1.Meanwhile the pound surged to its highest level in a year, briefly rising above $1.35, 
after a government official expressed confidence on reaching a post-Brexit trade deal with the EU. Nancy Pelosi 
has welcomed a bipartisan stimulus proposal that investors hope can break a months-long deadlock with 
Republicans Photo: AFP / Nicholas Kamm New York - Dow: UP 0.3 percent at 29,969.52 (close)New York - 
S&#38;P 500: DOWN 0.1 percent at 3,666.72 (close)New York - Nasdaq: UP 0.2 percent at 12,377.18 
(close)London - FTSE 100: UP 0.4 percent at 6,490.27 (close)Frankfurt - DAX 30: DOWN 0.5 percent at 13,252.86 
(close)Paris - CAC 40: DOWN 0.2 percent at 5,574.36 (close)EURO STOXX 50: DOWN 0.1 percent at 3,517.10 
Boeing Shares Surge On Big 737 MAX Order, Global Stocks Mixed
(close)Tokyo - Nikkei 225: FLAT at 26,809.37 (close)Hong Kong - Hang Seng: UP 0.7 percent at 26,728.50 
(close)Shanghai - Composite: DOWN 0.2 percent at 3,442.14 (close)Euro/dollar: UP at $1.2147 from $1.2115 at 
2200 GMTPound/dollar: UP at $1.3453 from $1.3365Dollar/yen: DOWN at 103.84 yen from 104.42 yenEuro/pound: 
DOWN at 90.28 pence from 90.65 penceWest Texas Intermediate: UP 0.8 percent at $45.64 per barrelBrent North 
Sea crude: UP 1.0 percent at $48.71 per barrel

Ryanair firms options for 75 B737-8-200s
Ryanair firms options for 75 B737-8-200s
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
December 03, 2020
Copyright 2020 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business News; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 328 words
Body
Ryanair (FR, Dublin Int'l) has firmed options for seventy-five B737-8-200s to increase its total commitment to the 
type to 210 units. The Irish low-cost carrier initially ordered 100 B737-8-200s in 2014, along with 100 options. It 
ordered an additional ten aircraft in 2017 and converted 25 options into firm orders in 2018. It is one of only two 
customers for the variant, the other being VietJetAir (VJ, Hanoi) with a firm order for 28 units of the type. 
The ch-aviation fleets advanced module shows that at least 135 of Ryanair's 210 aircraft, including 129 to be 
operated by Ryanair (FR, Dublin Int'l) itself and six by its Polish subsidiary Buzz (RR, Warsaw Modlin), have 
already been assigned and are awaiting delivery. The -200 is a higher capacity variant of the B737-8, featuring, 
among other modifications, an additional pair of exit doors. In Ryanair's configuration, the aircraft will seat up to 197 
passengers in a single-class layout. The B737-8-200 has yet to be certified as it was not prior to the March 2019 
grounding. The variant's certification aside, Michael O'Leary, Ryanair Holdings' Group CEO and Executive Director, 
said during a 1H FY2021 earnings call last month that the first MAX 8-200 could deliver during early 2021. "We are 
hoping to take the first delivery of those aircraft at the end of - sometime in February," he said. "It would allow us to 
take something of the order of about 30 aircraft between February and early summer. That figure might fall to 25 or 
so, but it depends on when we can get the first one." The entire 210-strong order is expected to be fulfilled by 
December 2024.

globe 
with

Ryanair firms options for 75 B737-8-200s
Ryanair firms options for 75 B737-8-200s
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
December 03, 2020
Copyright 2020 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business News and Features; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 328 words
Body
Ryanair (FR, Dublin Int'l) has firmed options for seventy-five B737-8-200s to increase its total commitment to the 
type to 210 units. The Irish low-cost carrier initially ordered 100 B737-8-200s in 2014, along with 100 options. It 
ordered an additional ten aircraft in 2017 and converted 25 options into firm orders in 2018. It is one of only two 
customers for the variant, the other being VietJetAir (VJ, Hanoi) with a firm order for 28 units of the type. 
The ch-aviation fleets advanced module shows that at least 135 of Ryanair's 210 aircraft, including 129 to be

Ryanair orders more Boeing MAX-8200 aircraft
Ryanair orders more Boeing MAX-8200 aircraft
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
December 03, 2020
Copyright 2020 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business News; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 956 words
Body
Ryanair, has signed a purchase agreement with Boeing for 75 new MAX-8200 aircraft, which increases its firm 
order for the Boeing "Gamechanger" aircraft from 135 to 210, with a total value of over US$22bn. Now that the 
Boeing MAX aircraft has been certified by the FAA to return to service, Ryanair expects to take the first deliveries of 
these new fuel efficient and environmentally friendly aircraft from early 2021, and has confirmed 210 firm orders 
with Boeing for these gamechanger aircraft, which will be delivered over a 4-year period between Spring 2021 and 
December 2024.
Ryanair, which (prior to the COVID-19 crisis) was on track to carry over 150m passengers last year, will use these 
new aircraft to grow its low fare services into new EU countries and markets, which will incentivize Europe's 
consumers and its travel industry to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic, as quickly as multiple vaccines are 
rolled out in 2021, and life returns to normal. Ryanair and Boeing have agreed revised delivery dates, and have also 
agreed compensation for the direct costs incurred by Ryanair over the past 18 months due to these delivery delays, 
although some of this compensation has been factored into a modest reduction in the pricing of this new aircraft 
order which has encouraged Ryanair to increase the firm order from 135 to 210 aircraft.
The Boeing 737 MAX-8200 aircraft is a "Gamechanger" for Ryanair's customers and Europe's consumers. This 
aircraft, when delivered, will be the most audited, most regulated in aviation history. The aircraft performance is 
exceptional, as it delivers 8 more seats per flight, yet burns 16% less fuel, and lowers noise emissions by 40%. This 
new 197 seat Boeing aircraft is the perfect sized platform to allow Ryanair expand and grow its low fare services 
across Europe over the next decade. This new Boeing order helps Ryanair to lower its cost base and return to 
growth across Europe in 2021, by delivering lower fares to customers, as well as a lower CO2 and noise footprint, 
making Ryanair Europe's greenest, cleanest airline, and helping Ryanair reach its target of being carbon neutral by 
2050.
Boeing's President & CEO Dave Calhoun said: "Ryanair will continue to play a leading role in our industry when 
Europe recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic and air traffic returns to growth across the continent. We are 
gratified that Ryanair is once again placing its confidence in the Boeing 737 family and building their future fleet with 
this enlarged firm order.
Boeing remains focused on safely returning the full 737 fleet to service and on delivering the backlog of airplanes to 
Ryanair and our other customers in the new year. We firmly believe in this airplane and we will continue the work to 
re-earn the trust of all of our customers."
Ryanair orders more Boeing MAX-8200 aircraft
Ryanair's Group CEO Michael O'Leary said: "We are pleased and proud to place this enlarged order with Boeing, 
who have successfully completed the return to service of the Boeing MAX aircraft. The Boeing MAX is a fabulous 
aircraft with more seats, more leg room, lower fares, lower fuel consumption, and it sets incredible environmental 
standards, including 40% less noise and lower CO2 emissions.
 We hope to take delivery of at least 50 of these aircraft in 2021, subject to Boeing recovering its manufacturing 
output to deliver them. For as long as the COVID-19 pandemic depresses air travel, we will use these new aircraft 
to replace some of our older Boeing NG fleet, which will remain  grounded until pre-Covid demand returns. But as 
soon as the COVID-19 virus recedes - and it will in 2021 with the rollout of multiple effective vaccines - Ryanair and 
our partner airports across Europe will - with these environmentally efficient aircraft - rapidly restore flights and 
schedules, recover lost traffic and help the nations of Europe recover their tourism industry, and get young people 
back to work across the cities, beaches, and ski resorts of the EU.
We sincerely thank our partners in Boeing, who have worked closely with us over the last 18 months to reschedule 
aircraft deliveries, to provide fair compensation to reflect those costs which Ryanair has incurred through these 
delivery delays and to agree this new enlarged aircraft order. We are working closely with Boeing and our senior 
pilot professionals to assist our regulator EASA to certify these aircraft in Europe, and to complete the training of 
our pilots and crews across our three new Boeing MAX simulators in Dublin and Stansted.
We are extremely grateful to our shareholders who have recently supported a (EURO)1.25 billion fundraising, 
without which we could not have placed this large but very timely aircraft order during a once in a century downturn 
in the airline industry. We believe our people will enjoy flying these exciting new aircraft, which will, we hope, allow 
us to recruit/train many thousands of new pilots and cabin crew over the next 5 years. The Board and people of 
Ryanair are confident that our customers will love these new aircraft, they will enjoy the new interiors, the more 
generous leg room, the lower fuel consumption and the quieter noise performance, but most of all, they will love the 
lower fares, which these aircraft will enable Ryanair to offer not just in 2021, but for the next decade, as Ryanair 
leads a strong recovery of Europe's aviation and tourism industry out of the 2020 COVID-19 crisis."
AirGuide and Pyramid Media connects you to an affluent, influential group of business and leisure travelers from

globe

and For Tech and Content Solutions.

in the airline industry. We believe our people will enjoy flying these exciting new aircraft, which will, we hope, allow
